revision.text:
{{Infobox book | name = 101 Philosophy Problems | title_orig = | translator = | image = Martin Cohen - 101 philosophy problems.jpeg | caption = | author = Martin Cohen | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = UK | language = English | series = | subject = [[Philosophy]] | genre = popular philosophy | published = 1999 (Routledge Taylor Francis) | media_type = Paperback, hardback, electronic | pages = 238 (third edition, 2007) | isbn = 978-0-415-40402-0 | dewey= 100 22 | congress= BD21 .C635 2007 | oclc= 75713360 | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''101 Philosophy Problems''''' (1999) is a philosophy book for a general audiences by [[Martin Cohen (philosopher)|Martin Cohen]] published by Routledge.
==Format and summary== The format of the book was unique and later copied by other authors. For example, in [[Julian Baggini]]'s ''The Pig That Wants to Be Eaten'' it was observed that the books "format is essentially the same as that first successfully introduced by Martin Cohen's ''101 Philosophy Problems''."<ref>Law, Stephen. "Saturday Review: Science & philosophy: Food for thought: Stephen Law on moral dilemmas: The Pig That Wants to Be Eaten, and Ninety-Nine Other Thought Experiments by [[Julian Baggini]] 256pp, Granta, pounds 14.99". ''The Guardian'' [London (UK)] 03 Sep 2005: 11.</ref>
In a review for the ''[[Times Higher Education Supplement]]'' (London),<ref>Harry Gensler, ''Times Higher Education Supplement'', February 25, 2000</ref> Harry Gensler, Professor of philosophy, at John Carroll University, Cleveland, describes the book:
:"The book has 101 humorous little stories, each with a philosophical problem (not however, necessarily, the usual [[Unsolved problems in philosophy]]). For example, problem 54 is about Mr Megasoft, who dies leaving his fortune to his favourite computer. Megasoft's children take the matter to court, contending that the computer cannot think and so cannot inherit money. Mr Megasoft's lawyers claim that the computer can think. But on what grounds can we say that computers can or cannot think?"
Other stories deal with [[paradoxes]], ethics, aesthetics, perception, time, God, physics, and knowledge and include problems from Zeno, Descartes, Russell, Nelson Goodman, Edmund Gettier and others. The problems are followed by a discussion section and a glossary.
==Reception== In a review for ''[[The Philosopher]]'', Dr. Zenon Stavrinides says that:
:"Both in regard to its structure and the style in which it is written, it is very unconventional. The first part of the book consists of a series of very short stories or narrative texts, grouped by subject-matter, setting out problems or puzzles of philosophical interest. Some of these problems are well-known in philosophical literature, e.g. the [[Epimenides paradox|paradox of Epimenides the Cretan]], who said: 'All Cretans are liars'. In the second part of the book, entitled 'Discussions', Cohen provides explanations and analyses of the issues raised by each of the problems, with some references to the treatment offered by particular historical philosophers. These discussions are intelligent and balanced, if (in most cases at least) inevitably inconclusive."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.the-philosopher.co.uk/reviews/202revs.htm |title=Philosophy Problems, official website |accessdate=2012-11-15 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101031045351/http://www.the-philosopher.co.uk/reviews/202revs.htm |archivedate=2010-10-31 |df= }}</ref>
''101 Philosophy Problems'' has been reviewed in ''The Philosophers Magazine'' by [[Julian Baggini]] (Summer 1999);<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thephilosophersmagazine.com/TPM/article/view/12530 |title=Fresh directions: 101 Philosophy Problems, Martin Cohen (Routledge) £8.99 Key Philosophers in Conversation, Ed. Andrew Pyle (Roudedge) £12.99 |work=The Philosophers Magazine |first=Julian|last=Baggini|authorlink=Julian Baggini |date=Summer 1999 |accessdate=November 15, 2012}}</ref> the ''Ilkley Gazette'' (May 29, 1999 );{{citation needed|date=November 2012}} ''The Guardian'' (5.11.1999);<ref>"This week: five books of philosophy, to save you the burden of reading them." ''Guardian'' [London, England] 5 Nov. 1999: 16. ''Infotrac Newsstand''. Retrieved 15 Nov. 2012.</ref> and ''Der Spiegel'' (2001).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/unispiegel/d-20452859.html |title=Martin Cohen: 99 Philosophische Rätsel |work=[[Der Spiegel]] |author= |language=German |year=2001 |accessdate=November 15, 2012}}</ref>
==Editions== It has had three English editions and been translated into German, Dutch, Greek, Estonian, Korean, Chinese, Spanish, Portuguese, Japanese and other languages. The German translation has alone run to three editions, one by Campus and two by Piper, including a massmarket hardback edition. There also an edition in [[Persian language|Persian]].
==References== {{Reflist}}
;Additional reviews *"101 Philosophy Problems, 2nd Ed." ''CHOICE: Current Reviews for Academic Libraries'' Sept. 2002: 114. Academic OneFile. *"101 Philosophy Problems." ''Philosophy in Review'' 20 (2000): 244. Academic OneFile. *"101 Philosophy Problems." ''Publishers Weekly'' 19 July 1999: 178. Academic OneFile.
==External links== *{{cite web|url=http://www.the-philosopher.co.uk/101-links.htm |title=Philosophy Problems, official website |accessdate=2008-09-07 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719173905/http://www.the-philosopher.co.uk/101-links.htm |archivedate=2011-07-19 |df= }}
[[Category:1999 books]] [[Category:Philosophy books]] [[Category:Routledge books]] [[Category:Public philosophy]] [[Category:Philosophy education]]

{{refimprove|date=March 2010}} An '''Abendrealschule''' ("Evening Realschule") is a German class of secondary school for mature students which allows them to gain the [[Mittlere Reife]] and sometimes also other school leaving certificates.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.do.shuttle.de/do/ars-do/ |title=Abendrealschule Dortmund |publisher=Do.shuttle.de |date= |accessdate=2014-05-24}}</ref> Classes are usually held in the evening.
== See also ==
*[[Abendhauptschule]] *[[Abendgymnasium]]

revision.comment: [[WP:AES|←]]Created page with ''''Antoine-François Botot''', known as '''Dangeville''' (26 May 1681 - c.1737) was a French dancing master, dancer and ballet teacher. He was born in Paris. Hi...'
revision.text:
'''Antoine-François Botot''', known as '''Dangeville''' (26 May 1681 - c.1737) was a French dancing master, dancer and ballet teacher.
He was born in Paris. His brother was the actor [[Charles Botot Dangeville]]. He made his début at the [[Académie royale de musique]] in 1701 and retired in 1748, although he remained a member of the [[Académie royale de danse]] until his death. Campardon lists Dangeville's roles<ref>{{fr icon}} Émile Campardon, ''L'Académie royale de musique au xviiie siècle'', Paris, Berger-Levrault, 1884, vol. I, pp. 162-168.</ref>
He married the actress [[Anne-Catherine Desmares]] in 1707, with whom he had two sons and a daughter, who all became actors - the most notable was the daughter [[Marie-Anne Botot Dangeville]].
==References== <references/>
{{DEFAULTSORT:Dangeville}} [[category:French male dancers]] [[category:Ballet masters]] [[Category:Paris Opera Ballet]] [[Category:Troupe of the Comédie-Française]] [[category:People from Paris]] [[category:1681 births]] [[category:1737 deaths]]

revision.text:
{{coord|37.33182|-122.03118|region:US-CA|display=title}} {{Infobox university | name = Apple University | image = Apple Headquarters in Cupertino.jpg | caption = [[Apple Campus]] (1 [[Infinite Loop (street)|Infinite Loop]], [[Cupertino, California]]) |motto = |established = {{start date|2008}} |type = [[Corporate university]] |president = |chairman =[[Joel Podolny]], Dean |head_label = |head = [[Joel Podolny]] |city = [[Cupertino, California|Cupertino]] |state = [[California]] |country = United States |endowment = |students = |faculty = |nickname = |website = |logo =Apple logo black.svg |logo_size =80px |coor = |campus = [[Suburban]] |colors = |affiliations = [[Apple Inc.]] }} '''Apple University''' is a [[training]] facility of [[Apple Inc.]], located in [[Cupertino, California]]. This [[corporate university]] was designed to instruct personnel employed by Apple in the various aspects of Apple's technology and corporate culture.
==History== [[Steve Jobs]] established Apple University in 2008 as a way to inculcate employees into Apple’s business culture and educate them about its history, particularly as the company grew. The program was devised by Joel Podolny, then the dean of Yale School of Management. Jobs selected him when the program was founded, and Podolny remains head of the program and effectively serves as dean of the university. He also is a vice president at Apple.<ref name="peterburrows"/><ref name="auto">https://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/11/technology/-inside-apples-internal-training-program-.html New York Times</ref>
Courses are not required, only recommended. Employees sign up for courses tailored to their positions and backgrounds on an internal website available only to Apple staff members.
It is highly secretive<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2014/aug/11/apple-university-employees-staff-steve-jobs|title=Apple University: where employees are not born, but made|author=Samuel Gibbs|work=the Guardian}}</ref> and rarely written about.<ref name="auto"/> Employees are strongly discouraged from talking about the company in general, including Apple University. No pictures of the classrooms have surfaced publicly.
Apple has strenuously pursued the vision that function and beauty come from simplicity,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnet.com/news/apple-university-preaches-mantra-of-simplicity-to-employees/|title=Apple University preaches mantra of simplicity to employees|publisher=CBS Interactive|work=CNET}}</ref> and teachers in its internal training program sometimes point to a collection of Picasso lithographs that illustrate the drive to boil down ideas to their most essential components.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2014/8/10/5989837/at-apple-university-studying-picasso-helps-with-product-design|title=At Apple University, studying Picasso helps with product design|author=Sam Byford|publisher=Vox Media|work=The Verge}}</ref>
==Academic staff and instructors== The full-time members of the faculty design and teach the courses. Faculty members include professors from universities like [[Yale]]; [[Harvard]]; the [[University of California-Berkeley]]; [[Stanford]]; and [[M.I.T.]] Some of the faculty continue to hold positions at their universities while also working for Apple.<ref name="auto1">{{cite web|url=http://fortune.com/2013/02/13/apple-university-hires-another-high-profile-academic/|title=Apple University hires another high-profile academic|work=Fortune}}</ref>
The instructors include: *[[Tim Cook]], CEO.<ref name="peterburrows">{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2014-02-13/why-apple-university-matters-more-than-ever|title=Why Apple University Matters More Than Ever|author=Peter Burrows|work=Bloomberg.com}}</ref> *[[Joel Podolny]], formerly the dean of Yale School of Management <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stxavier.org/page.cfm?p=1&newsid=2947|title=The Jesuit High School in Cincinnati: Keeper of the Apple Culture|work=stxavier.org}}</ref> *[[Richard S. Tedlow|Richard Tedlow]], a Harvard University business historian.<ref name="peterburrows"/> *Randy Nelson who came from the animation studios Pixar<ref name="nytimes.com">https://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/11/technology/-inside-apples-internal-training-program-.html</ref> and DreamWorks Animation *[[Joshua Cohen (philosopher)|Joshua Cohen]], a Stanford professor<ref name="nytimes.com"/> *Morten Hansen, of Berkeley <ref name="auto1"/>
==Courses== Some of the courses teach case studies about important business decisions that Apple made. These strategic decisions include the one to make the iPod and its iTunes software compatible with Microsoft’s Windows system. This was a topic of fierce debate internally at Apple with Steve Jobs strongly opposing the notion of sharing the iPod with Windows. Jobs eventually gave in to his lieutenants. It turned out that opening the iPod to Windows users led to explosive growth of the music player and the iTunes Store, and this in turn would later be critical to the success of the iPhone.
''' “Communicating at Apple.” ''' This course focuses on clear communication for making products intuitive, sharing ideas within Apple, and marketing products.
''' “Project Management.” ''' No information provided, Course is confidential
''' “Vendor Management.” '''
'''“What Makes Apple, Apple.”''' Focuses on one of Jobs's goals: to make complex computer technologies feel understandable and natural. In the course an instructor showed a slide of the remote control for the Google TV. The remote had 78 buttons. Then the instructor, Nelson, showed a photo of the Apple TV remote, a thin rod with three buttons.<ref name="auto"/>
==Campus== The classes are taught on Apple’s corporate campus in Cupertino, California. Apple University is in a section of buildings called City Center. The rooms are built in a trapezoid shape. Occasionally, classes are offered in Apple’s offices overseas, and the professors travel there to teach.
In 2014, Apple planned an expansion of Apple University to China, to include a Dean to run Apple University China.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://9to5mac.com/2014/11/03/apple-plans-apple-university-in-china-bringing-jobs-vision-to-asia/|title=Apple plans Apple University in China, bringing Jobs’ vision to Asia|work=9to5Mac}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Hamburger University]] * [[Apple Inc.]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Apple Inc.}}
[[Category:Business education]] [[Category:Education in Santa Clara County, California]] [[Category:Apple Inc.]] [[Category:Cupertino, California]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2014}} {{Infobox scientist | name = Audrey Joan Butt Colson | image = <!--(filename only, i.e. without "File:" prefix)--> | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Audrey Joan Butt | birth_date = 1926 <!--{{birth date |YYYY|MM|DD}}--> | birth_place = | death_date = <!--{{death date and age |YYYY|MM|DD |YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date)--> | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!--{{coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline,title}}--> | other_names = | residence = | citizenship = | nationality = | fields = [[Social anthropology]] | workplaces = | patrons = | education = | alma_mater = [[University of Oxford]] | thesis_title = Systems of belief in relation to social structure and organisation (with reference to the Carib-speaking tribes of the Guianas) | thesis_url = http://solo.bodleian.ox.ac.uk/primo_library/libweb/action/dlDisplay.do?vid=OXVU1&docId=oxfaleph011827293 | thesis_year = 1954 | doctoral_advisor = <!--(or | doctoral_advisors = )--> | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = Study of the Amerindian peoples of Guyana, Brazil and Venezuela | influences = [[Edward Evans-Pritchard]] | influenced = [[Peter Rivière]]<ref>Peter Rivière, "Indians and Cowboys: Two Field Experiences", in ''Anthropologists in a Wider World'', edited by Paul Dresch, Wendy James and David Parkin (Berghahn Books, 2000), p. 31</ref> | awards = | author_abbrev_bot = | author_abbrev_zoo = | spouse = Robin Colson | children = | signature = <!--(filename only)--> | signature_alt = | website = <!--{{URL|www.example.com}}--> | footnotes = }}
'''Audrey Joan Butt Colson''' (born 1926),<ref name=LCCN>{{cite web|title=Colson, Audrey Butt |url= http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n87141946.html |publisher=Library of Congress|accessdate=28 December 2014 |quote=Colson, Audrey, 1926-; full name: Audrey Joan Butt Colson }}</ref> is a social anthropologist with a particular interest in the Amerindian peoples of Guyana, Brazil and Venezuela. She was, together with [[Peter Rivière]], one of the pioneers of Amazonian anthropology at the [[University of Oxford]].<ref name=Oxford>{{cite web | title= Amazonian Anthropology |url= http://www.isca.ox.ac.uk/research/amazonian-anthropology/ |publisher= Institute of Social and Cultural Anthropology, University of Oxford |accessdate=28 December 2014 }}</ref>
Part of the permanent endowment of the University of Oxford is a fund to support South American Amerindian Studies known as the Butt Colson Amerindian Studies Bequest.<ref> [http://www.ox.ac.uk/gazette/2004-5/weekly/140705/acts.htm University Acts], ''[[Oxford University Gazette]]'', 14 July 2005.</ref>
==Oxford University== Audrey Butt studied at Oxford under [[Edward Evans-Pritchard]], and carried out fieldwork among the [[Akawaio people]] in [[Guyana]] in 1951-1952 and in 1957, later broadening her study to include other [[Pemon]] and Kapon groups in Brazil, Guyana and Venezuela. She obtained the Diploma in Ethnology in 1949, the B.Litt. degree in 1950, and the D.Phil. in 1955. She then spent a year in Spain to learn Spanish in preparation for further fieldwork in South America.<ref>{{cite web | title= Annual Report of the Curator of the Pitt Rlvers Museum (Department of Ethnology) for the year ending 31 July 1955 |url= http://web.prm.ox.ac.uk/sma/index.php/museum-annual-reports/255-1954-55-annual-report.html |publisher=The invention of museum anthropology, 1850-1920, University of Oxford}}</ref>
In 1956 she lectured on South American societies at Oxford's [[Pitt Rivers Museum|Department of Ethnology]].<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Rival | first1 = Laura | title = Peter Rivière's contributions to Amazonian and Social Anthropology |journal= Journal of the Anthropological Society of Oxford |date=1999 |volume=30 |issue=3 |pages= 213–218 |url =https://www.isca.ox.ac.uk/fileadmin/ISCA/JASO/Archive_1999/30_3_Rival.pdf | format=pdf | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref>
==Pitt Rivers Museum== The South American collections of the [[Pitt Rivers Museum]] contain 310 Amerindian objects donated by Butt Colson as a result of her fieldwork.<ref>{{cite web | last1 = Rivière | first1 = Peter | title = South American Tropical Forest Material |url = http://www.prm.ox.ac.uk/South_America.html | publisher = [[Pitt Rivers Museum|Pitt Rivers Museum, University of Oxford]] }}</ref> The museum also holds two reels of 16mm film shot by [[Bassett Maguire]] in 1952 and a [[BBC]] recording of Akawaio music and songs made in 1961, all produced with Butt Colson’s assistance.
==Amerindian land disputes== In 2012 a judge in the Demerara High Court ruled that Dr Colson could not appear as an expert witness in a land suit brought by Akawaio and Arekuna Amerindian communities because of her prior support of the plaintiffs' position.<ref>{{cite web|title=Judge in Amerindian communities landmark case rules anthropologist Dr. Colson cannot be deemed an expert | url= http://guyanachronicle.com/judge-in-amerindian-communities-landmark-case-rules/|publisher=[[Guyana Chronicle]] | date = 7 May 2012 | accessdate = 28 December 2014 }}</ref>
In September 2013 [[Survival International]] published her report, ''Dug out, dried out or flooded out? Hydro Power and Mining Threats to the Indigenous Peoples of the Upper Mazaruni District, Guyana'',<ref>{{cite book | last = Butt Colson | first = Audrey | title =Dug out, dried out or flooded out? Hydro power and mining threats to the indigenous peoples of the Upper Mazaruni District, Guyana |url =http://assets.survivalinternational.org/documents/1113/book-fpic-oct-2.pdf | format=pdf | date = September 2013 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref> demonstrating that the government of Guyana's plans to build hydroelectric dams on the upper [[Mazaruni River]] would flood the entire territory of the Akawaio indigenous people.
==Works==
===Books=== * {{cite book | last = Butt | first = Audrey J. | title = The Nilotes of the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan and Uganda | publisher = [[International African Institute]] | location = London | year = 1952 | isbn = 9780853020295 }} * {{cite book | last1 = Baxter | first1 = Paul Trevor William | last2 = Butt Colson | first2 = Audrey | title = The Azande, and related peoples of the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan and Belgian Congo | publisher = International African Institute | series = Ethnographic survey of Africa | location = London | year = 1953 | oclc = 3352883 }} * [[Stewart Wavell]], Aufrey Butt, [[Nina Epton]], ''Trances'' (London: Allen & Unwin, 1966) * {{cite book | last = Butt Colson | first = Audrey | title = Fr Cary-Elwes S.J. and the Alleluia Indians | publisher = Amerindian Research Unit, [[University of Guyana]] | series = | location = [[Georgetown, Guyana]] | year = 1998 | isbn = 9789766240103 }} (see also [[Cuthbert Cary-Elwes]]) * {{cite book | last = Butt Colson | first = Audrey | title = Land: its occupation, management, use and conceptualization. The case of the Akawaio and Arekuna of the Upper Mazaruni District, Guyana | publisher = Last Refuge | series = | location = Panborough | year = 2009 | isbn = 9780954435073 }}<ref>Reviewed by Christopher Carrico in ''[[New West Indian Guide]]'', Vol. 86, No. 1/2 (2012), pp. 157-159.</ref>
===Journal articles and chapters in books=== * {{cite journal | last1 = Butt | first1 = Audrey J. | title = Ritual blowing: Taling – a causation and cure of illness among the Akawaio |journal= [[Man (journal)|Man]] |date=April 1956 |volume=56 |pages= 49–55 |url =https://dx.doi.org/10.2307/2793660 | doi=10.2307/2793660 | ref = harv | postscript = .| jstor = 2793660 }} * {{cite journal | last1 = Butt | first1 = Audrey J. | title = The birth of a religion: the origins of a semi-Christian religion among the Akawaio |journal= [[Journal of the Royal Anthropological Institute]] |date=January 1960 |volume=60 | issue = 1 |pages= 66–106 |url =https://dx.doi.org/10.2307/2844219 | doi=10.2307/2844219 | ref = harv | postscript = .| jstor = 2844219 }} * {{cite journal | last1 = Butt | first1 = Audrey J. | title = Symbolism and ritual among the Akawaio of British Guiana |journal= [[New West Indian Guide]] |date=1961 |volume=41 |issue=1 |pages= 141–161 |url =https://dx.doi.org/10.1163/22134360-90002345 | doi=10.1163/22134360-90002345 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} * {{cite journal | last1 = Butt Colson | first1 = Audrey J. | title = Hallelujah among the Patamona Indians |journal= Antropológica |date=1971 |volume=28 |pages= 25–58 | oclc=883788082 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} * {{cite journal | last1 = Butt Colson | first1 = Audrey J. | title = Inter-tribal trade in the Guiana Highlands |journal= Antropológica |date=1973 |volume=34 |pages= 1–70 | oclc=883788237 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} * {{citation | last1 = Butt | first1 = Audrey J. | contribution = The Akawaio Shaman | editor-last = Basso | editor-first = Ellen B. | title = Carib-speaking Indians: culture, society, and language | publisher = University of Arizona Press | pages= 43–65 | location = Tucson | year = 1977 | isbn = 9780816504930 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}
===Reports=== *''[http://assets.survivalinternational.org/documents/1113/book-fpic-oct-2.pdf Dug out, dried out or flooded out? Hydro Power and Mining Threats to the Indigenous Peoples of the Upper Mazaruni District, Guyana]'', [[Survival International]], September 2013.
==External links== *{{IMDb name|2617637}} *Audrey Butt Colson website: https://buttcolson.com
