revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = ByWater Solutions LLC | type = Private | logo = | foundation = 2009 | location_city = Santa Barbara, CA
New Haven, CT | location_country = USA | industry = [[Computer software]] | products = [[Koha (software)|Koha]] (Support) | homepage = [http://bywatersolutions.com/ http://bywatersolutions.com/] }} '''ByWater Solutions''' is a privately owned and funded company founded in March 2009 by CEO Brendan A. Gallagher and EVP Nathan A. Curulla,{{cite web |title=ByWater Solutions Company Profile |url=http://www.librarytechnology.org/bywater.pl |work=LibraryTechnology.org |accessdate=9 December 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111129093501/http://www.librarytechnology.org/bywater.pl |archivedate=29 November 2011 |df= }}{{cite web|title=ByWater Solutions: About Us|url=http://bywatersolutions.com/about-us/|work=ByWater Solutions|accessdate=9 December 2011}} which provides implementation, hosting, support, consultation, and development services for the [[Koha (software)|Koha Integrated Library System]].{{cite web|last=Breeding|first=Marshall|title=lib-web-cats|url=http://www.librarytechnology.org/libraries.pl?ILS=Koha%20--%20ByWater%20Solutions|work=lib-web-cats|accessdate=9 December 2011}}{{cite web|title=Koha Paid Support|url=http://koha-community.org/support/paid-support/country/#usa|work=Koha|accessdate=9 December 2011}}{{cite journal|last=Breeding|first=Marshall|title=Automation Marketplace 2011: The New Frontier|journal=Library Journal|date=April 1, 2011|url=http://www.libraryjournal.com/lj/home/889533-264/automation_marketplace_2011_the_new.html.csp|accessdate=12 December 2011}} ==History== After the founding of ByWater Solutions in 2009, Gallagher began contributing to the Koha community by way of small developmental fixes. ByWater signed their first contract in June 2009.{{cite web|title=ByWater Solutions Listed as an Official Koha Support Company|url=http://www.librarytechnology.org/ltg-displaytext.pl?RC=13919|work=LibraryTechnology.org|accessdate=9 December 2011}}{{cite web|last=Rogers|first=Michael|title=InfoTech Briefs: Credo, EBSCO, Serials Solutions|url=http://www.libraryjournal.com/slj/technologytoolsandtrends/854815-358/infotech_briefs_credo_ebsco_serials.html.csp|work=Library Journal|accessdate=12 December 2011|date=April 28, 2009}} Since that time, ByWater has grown to a Koha dedicated staff of 25,{{cite web|title=ByWater Solutions: About Us|url=http://bywatersolutions.com/about-us/|work=ByWater Solutions|accessdate=9 December 2011}} and supports over 1,100{{cite web|title=lib-web-cats|url=http://www.librarytechnology.org/lwc-processquery.pl?code=lwc&Quick=bywater&submit=view|work=LibraryTechnology.org|accessdate=9 December 2011}} library sites (including publics,{{cite web|title=America’s First Public Koha Library Chooses ByWater Solutions|url=http://liswire.com/content/america%E2%80%99s-first-public-koha-library-chooses-bywater-solutions|work=LISWire|accessdate=12 December 2011}} schools, academic,{{cite journal|last=Wale|first=Carla P.|title=Cloudy with a Chance of Open Source: Open Source Integrated Library Systems and Cloud Computing in Academic Law Libraries|journal=Legal Reference Services Quarterly|year=2011|volume=30|pages=310–331|doi=10.1080/0270319X.2011.626324}} small non profits{{cite web|last=Rapp|first=David|title=Nonprofit Brings Open Source ILS to Libraries in Military Installations|url=http://www.libraryjournal.com/lj/home/891475-264/nonprofit_brings_open_source_ils.html.csp|work=Library Journal|accessdate=12 December 2011|date=1 August 2011}} and special libraries{{cite journal|last=Morton-Owens|first=Emily G.|author2=Karen L. Hanson |author3=Ian Walls |title=Implementing Open-Source Software for Three Core Library Functions: A Stage-by- Stage Comparison|journal=Journal of Electronic Resources in Medical Libraries|year=2011|volume=8|issue=1|pages=1–14|doi=10.1080/15424065.2011.551486}}{{cite journal|last=Wale|first=Carla P.|title=Cloudy with a Chance of Open Source: Open Source Integrated Library Systems and Cloud Computing in Academic Law Libraries|journal=Legal Reference Services Quarterly|year=2011|volume=30|pages=310–331|doi=10.1080/0270319X.2011.626324}}) within North America. Since its founding, ByWater has also partnered with other open source software companies worldwide to work on improving the Koha project both with documentation and developments.{{cite web|last=Cormack|first=Chris|title=ByWater Solutions and BibLibre partner in US|url=http://blog.bigballofwax.co.nz/2010/01/14/bywater-solutions-and-biblibre-partner-in-us/|accessdate=12 December 2011}}{{cite web|last=Bowen Ayre |first=Lori |title=More Breaking News! BibLibre to do Koha development for ByWater Solutions Customers |url=http://opensource.califa.org/node/93 |work=Open Source Open Libraries |accessdate=12 December 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120426050329/http://opensource.califa.org/node/93 |archivedate=26 April 2012 |df= }}{{cite web|title=ByWater Solutions and BibLibre Welcome Nicole C. Engard|url=http://liswire.com/content/bywater-solutions-and-biblibre-welcome-nicole-c-engard|work=LISWire|accessdate=12 December 2011}}{{cite web|title=ByWater Solutions and software.coop Collaborating on Koha EDI Support|url=http://www.software.coop/news/koha-edi/|work=software.coop|accessdate=12 December 2011}}{{cite web|title=Six Libraries Partner to Bring DOM Biblio Indexing to Koha|url=http://bywatersolutions.com/2012/02/02/six-libraries-partner-to-bring-dom-biblio-indexing-to-koha/|accessdate=27 March 2012}} ===Origin of the company name=== ByWater Solutions is named after a village in [[J. R. R. Tolkien|J. R. R. Tolkien's]] epic trilogy [[The Lord of the Rings]]. [[Bywater (Middle-earth)#Westfarthing|Bywater]] is a village which is situated in close proximity to the [[Shire (Middle-earth)|Shire]], the home of [[Bilbo Baggins|Bilbo]] and [[Frodo Baggins]], who are the two main characters in the story. [[Bywater (Middle-earth)|Bywater]] was known primarily for the [[Minor places in Middle-earth#The Green Dragon|Inn of the Green Dragon]], a central meeting place for travelers and adventurers in the story. The Inn was a hub for the collaboration and exchange of news and ideas in the world of Middle Earth, and thus resembles the environment found in Koha and [[Open-source software|Open Source Software]] in general. Because of the company's primary dealings with libraries worldwide, the founders thought that it was important to incorporate a literary reference to the name of the company, and being lifelong childhood friends, this literary work has personal value to them both.{{cite web|title=Our History|work=ByWater Solutions|url=http://bywatersolutions.com/about-us/history/|accessdate=25 October 2012}} === Partnerships === In March 2015, EBSCO Information Services and ByWater Solutions partnered together to allow libraries that use Koha ILS to easily integrate EBSCO Discovery Service™.https://www.ebsco.com/news-center/press-releases/ebscos-partnership-with-bywater-solutions-enables-interoperability Since then ByWater has expressed their commitment to support the FOLIO project in partnership with Ebsco.{{Cite news|url=https://www.ebsco.com/news-center/press-releases/folio-to-benefit-from-agreement-between-ebsco-and-bywater-solutions|title=FOLIO Library Services Platform to Benefit from Services Agreement Between EBSCO Information Services and ByWater Solutions|work=EBSCO|access-date=2018-04-16}} ===Honors=== In 2015, ByWater Solutions was recognized by Inc. Magazine as being one of the top 5,000 fastest growing business in the United States. ByWater was ranked number 3,862 out of the 5,000 businesses highlighted in the magazine’s annual spotlight.http://www.inc.com/inc5000/list/2015/ ByWater Solutions received the Platinum recognition in the 2017 Modern Library Awards.{{Cite news|url=https://bywatersolutions.com/2017/01/11/2017-modern-library-awards/|title=ByWater Solutions Receives Platinum in 2017 Modern Library Awards|date=2017-01-11|work=ByWater Solutions - Koha Open Source ILS Support|access-date=2018-04-16|language=en-US}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{DEFAULTSORT:ByWater Solutions}} [[Category:Free software companies]] [[Category:Library automation]] [[Category:Library-related organizations]] [[Category:Software companies based in California]] [[Category:Companies established in 2009]] [[Category:Companies based in California]] [[Category:Companies based in Connecticut]] [[Category:American companies established in 2009]] [[Category:Software companies established in 2009]]

revision.comment: The removed paragraph was an opinion about one failed piece of legislation and did not belong in the introductory paragraph.
revision.text:
{{ref improve|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox Union|<!-- Include all unused fields for future use. See [[template talk:Infobox Union]] for usage. --> |name= CTA |country= [[United States]] |affiliation= [[National Education Association|NEA]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cta.org/en/About-CTA.aspx|title=About CTA|last=|first=|date=|publisher=California Teachers Association|accessdate=2016-04-06}}</ref> |members= 325,000 |full_name= California Teachers Association |native_name= |image= [[Image:California TA logo.png]] |founded= May, 1863 |current= |head= |dissolved_date= |dissolved_state= |merged_into= |office= 1705 Murchison Drive, [[Burlingame, California]] |people= [[Eric C. Heins]], President |website= [http://www.cta.org www.cta.org] |footnotes= }} The '''California Teachers Association''' (CTA), initially established in 1863, is one of the largest and most powerful<ref>{{cite news | last = Skelton | first = George | title = Assemblywoman Bonilla, a former teacher, takes on the powerful union | newspaper = Los Angeles Times | date = June 27, 2016 | url = http://www.latimes.com/politics/la-pol-sac-skelton-teacher-tenure-bill-20160624-snap-story.html | access-date = October 3, 2016}}</ref> teachers' unions in California politics. It is based in [[Burlingame, California|Burlingame]], and its current president is Eric C. Heins.
==History== [[Image:CTAMainOffice.jpg|left|thumb| ''CTA's Governmental Affairs Office (Sacramento, CA)'']] CTA was founded in 1863, during the Civil War, in response to a call in 1863 from the California Superintendent of Public Instruction, [[John Swett]], for a "teachers' institute", about one hundred teachers gathered in [[San Francisco, California|San Francisco]], resulting in the formation of the California Educational Society. In 1875, the organization changed its name to the California Teachers Association.
CTA won its first major legislative victory in 1866 with a law providing free public schools to California children. A year later, public funding was secured for schools that educated nonwhite students. More early victories established bans on using public school funding for sectarian religious purposes (1878-79); free textbooks for all students in grades 1-8 (1911); the first teacher tenure and due process law (1912); and a statewide pension, the California State Teachers’ Retirement System (1913).
CTA led efforts to outlaw child labor in the state and enact other protections for children (1915), and to strengthen the teacher due process law (1921). In the 1940s, the union was the only major organization in California to protest against the internment of Japanese-Americans during World War II.
While the National Labor Relations Act of 1935 made collective bargaining a lawful, protected activity in the private sector, it did not include public workers or teachers. Wisconsin passed the nation's first public employee bargaining law (1959), and several large, urban affiliates of NEA or the American Federation of Teachers started winning bargaining rights (New York in 1961, Denver in 1962, Chicago in 1966). After a decade of school strikes and teacher organizing, California K-14 educators at last won the right to bargain collectively in 1975 when the CTA-sponsored Educational Employment Relations Act, also known as the Rodda Act, was signed into law by Gov. [[Jerry Brown]].
A turning point in CTA's history came in 1988. That was the year teachers fought to pass Proposition 98, the landmark state law guaranteeing about 40 percent of the state's general fund for schools and community colleges.
In 2005, CTA ran numerous ads criticizing Governor [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]] for refusing to pay back $2 billion that the Governor had "borrowed" from the education budget. CTA strongly opposed propositions [[California Proposition 74 (2005)|74]], [[California Proposition 75 (2005)|75]], [[California Proposition 76 (2005)|76]], which were advanced by Schwarzenegger. None of the initiatives were approved by voters. CTA also criticized Governor Schwarzenegger for spending nearly $80 million on the special election.
CTA strongly opposed [[California Proposition 8 (2008)|Proposition 8]] and donated a total of $1.25 million to help fight the measure that would ban gay marriage, stating that the proposition would violate civil rights and that proponents' advertising made false claims about the effect the proposition would have on public school curricula.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.cta.org CTA.org] - California Teachers Association homepage * [http://cal-access.ss.ca.gov/Campaign/Committees/Detail.aspx?id=1018473&session=2009&type=monetary&view=contributions] Secretary of State Campaign Disclosure {{Portal|Organized labour}}

revision.text:
{{About||the film|Class Rank (film)}} {{Redirect|Percent plan|[[Abraham Lincoln]]'s plan for [[Reconstruction era of the United States|Reconstruction]] after the [[American Civil War]]|Ten percent plan}} '''Class rank''' is a measure of how a student's performance compares to other students in his or her [[class (education)|class]]. It is commonly also expressed as a [[percentile]]. For instance, a student may have a [[Grade Point Average|GPA]] better than 750 of his or her classmates in a graduating class of 800.
== Use in high schools == The use of class rank is currently in practice at about less than half of [[United States|American]] [[high school]]s.<ref name=CollegeBoard/> Large [[Public school (government funded)|public school]]s are more likely to rank their students than small [[private school]]s.<ref name=CollegeBoard>{{cite web|url=http://www.collegeboard.com/prof/counselors/apply/14.html |title=Counselor's Connection - Apply to College: Class Rank and College Admissions |accessdate=July 5, 2007 |publisher=The [[College Board]] }}</ref> Because many admissions officers were frustrated that many applications did not contain a rank, some colleges are using other information provided by high schools, in combination with a student's GPA to estimate a student's class rank. Many colleges{{weasel-inline|date=May 2015}} say that the absence of a class rank forces them to put more weight on [[standardized test]] scores.<ref name=NYT>{{Cite news | last=Finder | first=Alex | date=March 5, 2003 | title=Schools Avoid Class Ranking, Vexing Colleges | periodical=[[The New York Times]] | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/03/05/education/05rank.html |accessdate=July 5, 2007}}</ref>
== Use in college admissions == Colleges often use class rank as a factor in [[college admissions]], although because of differences in grading standards between schools, admissions officers have begun to attach less weight to this factor, both for granting admission, and for awarding [[scholarships]]. Class rank is more likely to be used at large schools that are more formulaic in their admissions programs.<ref name=CollegeBoard />
=== Percent plans === Some [[U.S. states]] guarantee that students who achieve a high enough class rank at their high school will be admitted into a [[State university system (United States)|state university]], in a practice known as ''percent plans''. Students in [[California]] who are in the top nine percent of their graduating class,<ref>http://admission.universityofcalifornia.edu/freshman/california-residents/index.html</ref> and students in [[Florida]] who are in the top twenty percent of their graduating class are guaranteed admission to some state school, but not necessarily any particular institution. The [[University of Alaska system]] awards an $11,000 scholarship for four years to students in the top 10% of their graduating class at Alaskan high schools. The top ten percent of students in [[Texas]] high schools are guaranteed admission to the [[List of colleges and universities in Texas#State universities|state school]] of their choice,<ref>{{cite journal | last = Lang | first = David M. | date = April 1, 2007 | title = Class Rank, GPA, and Valedictorians: How High Schools Rank Students | journal = American Secondary Education <!-- note that this is not actually a journal. But this citation template provides more parameters that are useful than {{citation}} does. --> | volume = 35 | issue = 2 | pages = 36–48 | issn = 0003-1003 <!-- Note: This is what Ebsco Host defines as the ISSN, but the link goes to a slightly different article --> | url = http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-1298329431.html | format = [[PDF]] (''login required - free trial available'') | accessdate = 2007-07-06 }}</ref> excluding the [[University of Texas]], which only allocates 75% of its incoming freshman class seats to top 7% members.<ref>{{cite web | title=The University of Texas at Austin to Automatically Admit Top 10 Percent of High School Graduates for 2011 |url=http://www.utexas.edu/news/2009/09/16/top7_percent/ | accessdate=2010-04-05}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Academic grading in the United States#Rank-based grading|Rank-based grading in the United States]] * [[Latin honors]] * [[Salutatorian]] * [[Valedictorian]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [https://www.nytimes.com/2002/04/14/education/desperately-seeking-diversity-the-10-percent-solution.html?emc=rss&partner=rssnyt DESPERATELY SEEKING DIVERSITY; The 10 Percent Solution] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20130408094432/http://www.thestudentranking.com/ A global student and university ranking system (www.thestudentranking.com]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Class Rank}} [[Category:Student assessment and evaluation]] [[Category:Educational evaluation methods]]

revision.text:
{{orphan|date=September 2011}}
The education system in [[Honduras]] is characterized by five stages of [[formal education]]; PrePrimary, Primary, Middle, Secondary, and Tertiary. [[Public education]] in Honduras is provided free for children aged 6 to 15 where it is mandatory for children to attend at the primary level (Age 6 to 12).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.classbase.com/Countries/Honduras/Education-System |title=Education System In Honduras |publisher=Classbase.com |date= |accessdate=2012-09-18}}</ref> The [[Honduran Constitution]] moreover stipulates that parents have the right to choose the education ; whether free or private, of their children.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.honduras.com/honduras-constitution-english.html |title=Constitution of Honduras - English Translation |publisher=Honduras.com |date= |accessdate=2011-09-17}}</ref>
[[World Bank]] statistics put the [[adult literacy]] rate (% of people ages 15 and above) of Honduras at 83.6%.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://data.worldbank.org/country/honduras |title=Honduras |publisher=WorldBank.org |date= |accessdate=2011-09-17}}</ref> However, [[UNESCO]] statistics reveal a 12% [[Repeater (student)|repeater rate]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://stats.uis.unesco.org/unesco/TableViewer/tableView.aspx?ReportId=186 |title=Repetition Rates and Percentage of Repeaters in Primary Education |publisher=UIS.UNESCO.org |date= |accessdate=2011-09-17}}</ref> and only an 80% progression and completion rate in [[primary education]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://stats.uis.unesco.org/unesco/TableViewer/tableView.aspx?ReportId=166 |title=Measures of Progression and Completion in Primary Education |publisher=UIS.UNESCO.org |date= |accessdate=2011-09-17}}</ref> Moreover, only 64.5% enroll for [[secondary education]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://data.worldbank.org/country/honduras |title=Honduras |publisher=WorldBank.org |date= |accessdate=2011-09-17}}</ref>
== Poverty ==
[[Poverty]] is rife in Honduras, with the poverty headcount ratio at national [[poverty line]] standing at 60% as of 2010.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://data.worldbank.org/country/honduras|title=Honduras Data|publisher=World Bank |year=2010 }}</ref> In typical situations, children have to quit school permanently to work at an early age to help support their families. Even though school is fully state-subsidized up till the 5th grade, many children are still unable to attend school because their families can not afford to buy uniforms and school supplies.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://armenianow.com/economy/30861/forbes_report_worst_economy_armenia |title=Armenia The Second Worse Economy in the World|publisher=Forbes |year=2011 }}</ref> A study conducted in 2006 by [[National Institute of Statistics (Honduras)|National Institute of Statistics]] estimated that as many as 368,000 of the 1.7 million children ages five to 12 did not receive schooling in that year.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2007/100644.htm |title=Honduras|publisher=US Department of State |year=2007 }}</ref>
== Gender inequality == Honduras is a [[Patriarchy|patriarchal society]], and males are favoured over females when it comes to [[education]]. While parents may send both genders to primary school; the females are likely the first to be withdrawn to help at home and made to work to provide income. This is further supported by the belief that occupational opportunities resulting from education are greater for males, as females have greater difficulty in finding jobs that match their academic credentials even if they have the same education level.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.honduras.com/honduras-constitution-english.html |title=Female Education in Honduras: The Creation of a Community of Congruence for Women |publisher=Cinthia Navin |date=Fall 2004 |accessdate=2011-09-17}}</ref> Both genders have equal access to the limited available educational facilities; however, attendance rates for females were slightly lower than for males.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2007/100644.htm |title=Honduras|publisher=US Department of State |year=2007 }}</ref>
== Education infrastructure == The quality of the [[curriculum]] in Honduran public schools is poor, evidenced by the fact that for much of the last century, Honduran students were required to memorize useless or impractical data at the expense of sharpening their reasoning powers and [[critical thinking]] skills. Teachers are paid low wages, they do not have access to effective teaching materials, and they are not trained in the latest technologies and current teaching methods. In addition, there is a scarcity of teachers, with a teacher:student ratio of 1:33 in 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://stats.uis.unesco.org/unesco/TableViewer/tableView.aspx?ReportId=3336&IF_Language=eng|title=Beyond 20/20 WDS - Table View -|publisher=UNESCO Institute for Statistics |date= |accessdate=2011-09-17}}</ref> The destruction of over 3000 schools nationwide caused by [[Hurricane Mitch]] further weakened the country’s poor education infrastructure.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dol.gov/ilab/media/reports/iclp/tda2001/honduras.htm#_ftnref1206|title=Bureau of International Labor Affairs (ILAB) - U.S. Department of Labor |publisher=United States Department of Labor|date= |accessdate=2011-09-17}}</ref>
==References== <references />
[[Category:Education in Honduras]]

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=September 2012}}
'''English language in the Netherlands''' refers to the use of the [[English language]] in the [[Netherlands]]. Research states that between 90%<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/public_opinion/archives/ebs/ebs_386_en.pdf|format=PDF|title=EUROPEANS AND THEIR LANGUAGES|website=Ec.europa.eu|accessdate=2017-08-23}}</ref> and 93%<ref>{{cite web|url=https://alisonedwardsdotcom.files.wordpress.com/2012/04/phd-thesis_edwards.pdf|title="English in the Netherlands: Functions, forms and attitudes" p. 316 and onwards|website=Alisonedwardsdotcom.files.wordpress.com|accessdate=23 August 2017}}</ref> of the Dutch population claims to be able to converse in English. According to some, the main reasons for the high degree of English speakers is the country's small size, dependency on international trade, and the use of [[subtitles]] for foreign languages on [[television]] rather than [[dubbing (filmmaking)|audio dubbing]]. Dutch's genealogical proximity to English is also noted as a significant factor; both languages are closely related [[West Germanic languages]].<ref name="English in Europe">{{cite book |title=English in Europe: The acquisition of a third language |year=2000 |publisher=Multilingual Matters, Ltd.|url=https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=iaEGdFnQDJcC&oi=fnd&pg=PR7&dq=English+language+in+the+Netherlands&ots=av9-zsVtXG&sig=5MfgtIiKM_asNihtUH2S3fpyPXo#v=onepage&q=English%20language%20in%20the%20Netherlands&f=false|author=Cenoz J., Jessner U.|accessdate=2009-09-04}}</ref> Occupations which require a complex knowledge of the English language, such as those in aviation and the sciences, are also abundant in the Netherlands. Furthermore, it is an official and the majority language in the Caribbean municipalities of [[Saba]] and [[Sint Eustatius]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wetten.overheid.nl/BWBR0028063/|title=Regeling - Invoeringswet openbare lichamen Bonaire, Sint Eustatius en Saba - BWBR0028063|website=Wetten.overheid.nl|accessdate=23 August 2017}}</ref>
==History== Various explanations contribute to the popularity of English in the Netherlands. Due to the small size and population of the Netherlands, and hundreds of years of having a trade and commerce economy, particularly between mainland Europe and the United Kingdom, the Dutch put strong emphasis on learning English and other foreign languages, especially German. The Netherlands was also liberated from the Germans by English speaking troops, boosting the status of the English language.{{Citation needed|date=May 2015}} In the following decades, with American-dominated globalization, English gradually increased in importance as a [[lingua franca]], at the expense of [[German language|German]] and [[French language|French]], both losing popularity as secondary languages in the latter part of the 20th century. This is in spite of the fact that German is linguistically much closer to Dutch than English, and that Germany is the most important trade partner of the Netherlands. Nevertheless, knowledge of more than one foreign language is still widespread compared to other states of the European Union.
In Amsterdam, in particular, visitors may get the impression that it is possible to live in the Netherlands for a long time without learning Dutch. A substantial number of the inhabitants of Amsterdam have English as their native language (mostly British and North American immigrants), however most of them make an effort to learn at least some Dutch. Nevertheless, in and around Amsterdam one may find announcements, traffic signs and advertisements in both Dutch and English, or even in English only (as in [[Schiphol Airport]]). Amsterdam however already has had an English speaking community for hundreds of years. A church worshipping in English, the [[English Reformed Church, Amsterdam|English Reformed Church]] was reopened for worship in 1607.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ercadam.nl/about-us/history/|title=History - English Reformed Church Amsterdam|website=Ercadam.nl|accessdate=23 August 2017}}</ref>
Nowadays, most important scholarly and scientific publications in the Netherlands are in English with the exception of government related and legal publications.
==English language education in the Netherlands== English is compulsory on all levels of [[Education in the Netherlands|the Dutch secondary education system]]. In addition: * Many [[elementary school]]s teach English in the upper grades. * A student has to score at least a 5.5/10 for English Language appoond Literature for their high school finals, or they will not graduate. Pupils learn Received Pronunciation/ Queen's English. Since high schools in the Netherlands have different levels of education (preparatory mid-level professional, higher general continued education , pre-university college/preparatory scientific education. A test from elementary school together with the advice of the teacher will determine which level a pupil will attend.) Where the first one will teach a pupil enough English to have simple conversations. The second will be focused on achieving the ability to speak formally and in a professional setting. The third is focused on understanding the most difficult kinds texts and communicating on a university/scientific level, which is a little bit more than a master in English needed for British universities would ask. Though without the proverbs and or sayings. * Around 100 schools offer [[bilingual education]] (Dutch / English). This concept was first introduced in several high schools, but has found its way to primary schools. The aim of bilingual education is for the students to obtain the same level of English as the native speakers of Great Britain.{{Citation needed|date=May 2015}} * The first university professor of English, Jan Beckering Vinckers, was appointed at the [[University of Groningen]] in 1885. * Most [[university]] [[master's degree]]s are in English, and an increasing number of [[bachelor's degree]]s are as well,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nrc.nl/international/article2187638.ece/English_takes_over_at_Dutch_universities|title=NRC|website=Nrc.nl|accessdate=23 August 2017}}</ref> and even the first degrees of community college given in English have made their way into existence. In addition, many degrees that are taught in Dutch utilise English language materials (e.g. books) and names. * Students are often taught to perform Internet searches in English, as the results of these obtain a far higher variety and extent of information compared to the Dutch equivalent.
==English language television in the Netherlands== In addition to the availability of the [[United Kingdom|British]] channels [[BBC One]], [[BBC Two|Two]] and [[BBC World|World]], the [[United States|American]] [[CNN]] and the English edition of [[Al Jazeera]], many programmes broadcast on Dutch channels are broadcast in English with Dutch [[subtitles]].<ref name="English in Europe"/> English language children's programmes, however, are usually [[Dubbing (filmmaking)|dubbed]]. Dubbed commercials, films and TV programmes (apart from animations and cartoons) have often come to be disliked by the Dutch public. People very much prefer these to be broadcast with subtitles, or even with no form of translation whatsoever.
Apart from this, there are a few television stations broadcasting in English, targeting the English speaking community of the Netherlands, such as [[AF-TV]], or dedicating large portions of airtime to programming in English, such as [[RTV7]] and Amsterdam local TV channel Salto 1. (See also: [[Television in the Netherlands#Television in other languages|Television in the Netherlands]])
==Dunglish== {{main|Dunglish}} Dunglish (called ''steenkolenengels'' in [[Dutch language|Dutch]] translating to ''coal English'') is a portmanteau of ''Dutch'' and ''English'' and a term often used pejoratively to refer to the mistakes native Dutch speakers make when speaking English.
==Linguistic anglophobia and the English disease== [[Anglophobia]], or more accurately linguistic anglophobia, within the European Dutch language area (i.e. the Netherlands and [[Flemish Community|Flanders]]) has evolved out of schools and companies switching to English as medium of communication and a large number of English [[loanword]]s in the Dutch language. Consequentially this has led to some anglophobia with some groups advocating to dispose of all English loanwords.
English disease (Dutch: ''Engelse ziekte'') is a pejorative term for the effect of the English language on the use of [[compound (linguistics)|linguistic compounds]] in written Dutch. The [[anglicism]]s (and sometimes [[American English|Americanisms]]) enter the written language as a result of being exposed to English words and expressions.
==See also== *[[Languages of the Netherlands]] *''[[The UnDutchables]]''
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.volkskrant.nl/archief_gratis/article693143.ece/Cursus_Engels Cursus Engels] Dutch language article about use of English in science and scholarship] column in the [[Volkskrant]] by Bram Buunk 1996 *[http://www.volkskrant.nl/archief_gratis/article719911.ece/Talenkennis Talenkennis] Dutch language column in the [[Volkskrant]] by Bram Buunk on 3 May 1997 *[https://alisonedwardsdotcom.files.wordpress.com/2012/04/phd-thesis_edwards.pdf English in the Netherlands Functions, forms and attitude by Alison Edwards Department of Theoretical and Applied Linguistics University of Cambridge Dissertation submitted for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy, April 2014]
{{Languages of the Netherlands}} {{English dialects by continent}}
[[Category:Education in the Netherlands]] [[Category:English as a second or foreign language]] [[Category:Languages of the Netherlands]] [[Category:Culture in Amsterdam]]

revision.comment: /* References */ Genetics
revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{Orphan|date=April 2015}} {{notability|Books|date=November 2013}} }}
{{Infobox book |name = G is for Genes: The Impact of Genetics on Education and Achievement |author = [[Robert Plomin]], [[Kathryn Ashbury]] |cover_artist = |published = November 2013 ([[Wiley Blackwell]]) |pages = 216 }} ''''' G is for Genes: The Impact of Genetics on Education and Achievement''''' is a 2013 book by [[Robert Plomin]], Professor of Behavioral Genetics at the Kings College London and [[Kathryn Ashbury]], lecturer in the Centre for Psychology and Education at the University of York. The book summarizes findings of behavioural genetics that are relevant to education and offers policy recommendations. It is written for a wide audience including parents, educators and policy makers.
==Part One: In theory== Part one consists of 11 chapters that present the field of behavioural genetics and what implications some findings have on education. It addresses issues such as twin studies, sex differences and socio-economic status. Part one is summarized in 7 "big ideas" which are the following:
===Achievement and Ability Vary, Partly for Genetic Reasons=== Average school performance doesn’t change the fact that half of the students will fall above and the other half below the average. Seeing those scoring below average as ‘failing’ wastes resources on approaches that have little or no effect. Instead of making pupils identical, the diversity should be embraced after providing a certain level of common education.<ref>G is for Genes: The Impact of Genetics on Education and Achievement, Wiley Blackwell, 2013, p. 141</ref>
===The Abnormal is Normal=== Students that are high performing or low performing are no more likely to be more genetically exceptional than an average student and same genes influence performance all across the distribution of performance. In other words, a math professor and a student struggling with mathematics are using the same genes when they perform mathematical tasks. There are many genes with small effect which are working together in an interplay with many environmental experiences and the same genes can have allelic differences. This is why turning on or off genes is unlikely to have large effects.<ref>G is for Genes: The Impact of Genetics on Education and Achievement, Wiley Blackwell, 2013, p. 142</ref><ref>https://www.economist.com/news/books-and-arts/21590881-genes-count-lot-schooling-whether-schools-can-adapt-knowledge-less</ref>
===Continuity is Genetic and Change is Environmental=== School performance is influenced by the same genes across life span and dramatic fluctuations in performance are likely to be caused by environment, not biology. Even though it’s likely that emerging biotechnology will make it possible to have predictive genetic information relevant to learning, the predictions can never reach full accuracy because of environmental factors.<ref>G is for Genes: The Impact of Genetics on Education and Achievement, Wiley Blackwell, 2013, p. 143</ref>
===Genes are Generalists and Environments are Specialists=== Genes that influence one cognitive ability are likely to influence others as well; for example high performance on a reading test predicts high performance on math test. Education, on the other hand, is more specific and increasing performance in one area doesn’t transmit to other areas to the same extent.<ref>''G is for Genes: The Impact of Genetics on Education and Achievement'', Wiley Blackwell, 2013, p. 144</ref>
===Environments are Influenced by Genes=== Genetics influence individuals as they select their environment.<ref>G is for Genes: The Impact of Genetics on Education and Achievement, Wiley Blackwell, 2013, p. 144</ref>
===The Environments that Matter the Most are Unique to Individuals=== Identical twins raised in same households and who are taught by the same teachers still differ from each other. The differences not explained by shared genes or family household, the "non-shared environment", accounts for most of the environmental influence.<ref>G is for Genes: The Impact of Genetics on Education and Achievement, Wiley Blackwell, 2013, p. 145</ref>
===Equality of Opportunity Requires Diversity of Opportunity=== Perfect equality of opportunity would still result in differences between individuals, but these differences would be more due to genetics. There is a need to introduce more choice so different natures can be nurtured to full potential.<ref>G is for Genes: The Impact of Genetics on Education and Achievement, Wiley Blackwell, 2013, p. 146</ref>
==Part Two: In Practice==
The part two consists of eleven practical policy recommendations and their genetic basis.
===Minimize the Core Curriculum and Test Basic skills=== The mandatory learning should be minimized to the skills that are required to succeed in society, such as reading and numeracy.<ref>G is for Genes: The Impact of Genetics on Education and Achievement, Wiley Blackwell, 2013, p. 161</ref>
===Increase Choice=== Pupils should be able to choose from a large variety of subject options according to their own interests, particularly as they get older.<ref>G is for Genes: The Impact of Genetics on Education and Achievement, Wiley Blackwell, 2013, p. 163</ref>
===Forget About Labels=== Extra help should be given to those who need it as quickly as possible with as little labels and bureaucracy as possible.<ref>G is for Genes: The Impact of Genetics on Education and Achievement, Wiley Blackwell, 2013, p. 165</ref>
===Teach the Child As Well As the Class=== Pupils should have an Individual Education Plan that would be reviewed and revised each year and would serve as the basis for their school-leaving certificate.<ref>G is for Genes: The Impact of Genetics on Education and Achievement, Wiley Blackwell, 2013, p. 166</ref>
===Teach Children How To Succeed=== IQ and self-confidence have a positive impact on education and both can be improved with coaching. Such coaching is described as "Thinking Skills Sessions" and should be provided for an hour every week for every student.<ref>G is for Genes: The Impact of Genetics on Education and Achievement, Wiley Blackwell, 2013, p. 168</ref>
===Promote Equal Opportunities from an Early Age as Foundation for Social Mobility in the Future=== Disadvantaged children from age 2 should be offered free high-quality preschool education. All children aged 3 – 4 should be offered high quality preschool education tailored according to their needs and extra support should be provided to all low-SES families from birth.<ref>G is for Genes: The Impact of Genetics on Education and Achievement, Wiley Blackwell, 2013, p. 170</ref>
===Equalize Extracurricular Opportunities at School=== The playing field for extracurricular activities should be made more equal by providing poor families with vouchers that can be exchanged to extracurricular activities based in schools or elsewhere.<ref>G is for Genes: The Impact of Genetics on Education and Achievement, Wiley Blackwell, 2013, p. 172</ref>
===Create a Two Stage PE System=== Pupils should first have a standardized PE program where they would be exposed to different activities. The next stage would be choice-driven and pupils would be given the opportunity to choose from the activities introduced to them in the earlier stage.<ref>G is for Genes: The Impact of Genetics on Education and Achievement, Wiley Blackwell, 2013, p. 172</ref>
===Change the Destination=== Make apprenticeships more attractive and affordable to employers and increase the number and variety of options available for work and college based vocational training.<ref>G is for Genes: The Impact of Genetics on Education and Achievement, Wiley Blackwell, 2013, p. 173</ref>
===Train New Teachers in Genetics and Give Them Tools to Put it Into Practice=== Include a course on genetics of learning in teacher training and make useful information about personalization of education available to all schools.<ref>G is for Genes: The Impact of Genetics on Education and Achievement, Wiley Blackwell, 2013, p. 175</ref>
===Big Is Beautiful=== Make the schools bigger to increase capability to provide larger variety of options. Make the links between different levels of schooling stronger.<ref>G is for Genes: The Impact of Genetics on Education and Achievement, Wiley Blackwell, 2013, p. 177</ref>
==Reception== The book sparked public debate and was for example featured in BBC radio programme [[The Moral Maze]]. [[Steven Pinker]] wrote in his review of the book "This may be the most important book about educational theory and practice in the new millennium, giving educators, policy-makers, and parents much to think about."<ref>http://eu.wiley.com/WileyCDA/WileyTitle/productCd-1118482786,subjectCd-ED05.html</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Education books]] [[Category:Genetics books]] [[Category:Genetics in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:2013 non-fiction books]] [[Category:2013 in education]] [[Category:2013 in science]]

revision.text:
'''Gary John Previts''' (born 1942) is an American accountant, Professor of Leadership and Enterprise Development and Professor of Accountancy at the [[Weatherhead School of Management]]. He is known for his work on the history of the theory and practice of [[accountancy]].<ref>[[Zeff, Stephen A.]] "[http://www.ruf.rice.edu/~sazeff/PDF/Horizons,%20Part%20II%20(print).pdf How the US accounting profession got where it is today: Part II]." ''Accounting Horizons'' 17.4 (2003): 267-286.</ref>
== Biography == Born in Cleveland, Ohio, where his father, a graduate from [[Teachers College, Columbia University]] worked as an educator. Previts obtained his BA from [[John Carroll University]], under the guidance of Professor of Accounting [[Francis J. McGurr]], in 1963. In 1964 he obtained his MA in accountancy at the [[Ohio State University]], and in 1972 his PhD at the [[University of Florida]].<ref name="AHoF 2015">[http://fisher.osu.edu/departments/accounting-and-mis/the-accounting-hall-of-fame/membership-in-hall/gary-john-previts/ Gary John Previts] at ''fisher.osu.edu.'' Accessed 2014-02-16.</ref><ref>Cooper, David J., and Keith Robson. "[http://farzadson.persiangig.com/other/CneaRkVXi4P.pdf#page=302 Accounting, professions and regulation: Locating the sites of professionalization]." ''Accounting, organizations and society'' 31.4 (2006): 415-444.</ref>
Previts served in the US Army in the [[Vietnam War]], where he was stationed in Thailand from 1965 to 1967. Back in the States he worked at [[Haskins & Sells]], now [[Deloitte]], before continuing his graduate study. After graduation Previts started his academic career at [[University of Alabama]] in 1973. During the first year of his academic career, Previts was instrumental in generating interest in and in the formation of the [[Academy of Accounting Historians]], devoted to the study of accounting history.<ref name>[[Edward N. Coffman]], [[Alfred R. Roberts]] and Gary John Previts, [http://www.accountingin.com/accounting-historians-journal/volume-16-number-2/a-history-of-the-academy-of-accounting-historians/ A history of the Academy of Accounting Historians 1973-1988]. ''[[Accounting Historians Journal]]'' 16:2 (1989). Retrieved 2015-08-20.</ref> He was the founding editor of the ''[[Accounting Historians Journal]]'' in 1974.<ref>"[http://clio.lib.olemiss.edu/cdm/ref/collection/aah/id/1520 Preface]," ''Accounting Historians Journal,'' 1974-1976, Vol. 1-3</ref> He is also the editor of ''[[Research in Accounting Regulation]]''.<ref>[[Elsevier]], [http://www.journals.elsevier.com/research-in-accounting-regulation/ Overview - ''Research in Accounting Regulation'']. Retrieved 2015-12-02.</ref> In 1979, Previts joined the Weatherhead School of Management at [[Case Western Reserve University]], where he was eventually appointed Professor of Leadership and Enterprise Development and Professor of Accountancy.<ref name="AHoF 2015"/>
Previts' research interests focus on the "development of accounting thought and institutions... the corporate origins and ongoing events that have shaped contemporary accounting practices... [and on] the regulation of accounting disclosures."<ref>[https://weatherhead.case.edu/faculty/gary-previts Gary Previts] at Weatherhead School of Management. Accessed 2014-02-16.</ref> Previts was inducted into the [[Accounting Hall of Fame]] in 2011.<ref name="AHoF 2015"/>
== Selected publications == * Previts, Gary John. ''The Scope of CPA Services: A Study of the Development of the Concept of Independence and the Profession's Role in Society.'' Ronald Press, 1985. * Magill, Harry T., and Gary John Previts. ''CPA professional responsibilities: An introduction.'' South-Western Pub, 1991. * [[Coffman, Edward N.]], Rasoul H. Tondkar, and Gary John Previts. ''Historical perspectives of selected financial accounting topics.'' Richard D. Irwin, Inc., 1993. * Previts, Gary John, and Barbara D. Merino. ''History of Accountancy in the United States: The Cultural Significance of Accounting.'' Ohio State University Press, 1998.
Articles, a selection<ref>[https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=rZo8dG4AAAAJ Google Scholar], profile.</ref> * Previts, Gary John, Lee D. Parker, and Edward N. Coffman. "Accounting history: definition and relevance." ''Abacus'' 26.1 (1990): 1-16. * Previts, Gary John, Lee D. Parker, and Edward N. Coffman. "An accounting historiography: subject matter and methodology." ''Abacus'' 26.2 (1990): 136-158. * Previts, G. J., Bricker, R. J., Robinson, T. R., & Young, S. J. "A content analysis of sell-side financial analyst company reports." ''Accounting Horizons'' 8 (1994): 55-55. * Previts, Gary John, and Robert Bricker. "Fact and Theory in Accounting History: Presentmindedness and Capital Market Research*." ''Contemporary Accounting Research'' 10.2 (1994): 625-641.
== References == {{reflist|2}}

revision.comment: Added {{[[:Template:third-party|third-party]]}} tag to article ([[WP:TW|TW]])
No indication that the women were actually members of Hehalutz. Stroop is the main source of this
revision.text:
[[File:HeHalutz logo.jpg|thumb|HeHalutz logo]] [[Image:Arie-Berlinski-Sarny-Chalutz3.jpeg|thumb|Polish HeHalutz membership card, 1924]] '''HeHalutz''' or '''Hechalutz ''' ({{lang-he-n|החלוץ}}, ''lit.'' The Pioneer) was a Jewish youth movement that trained young people for agricultural settlement in the [[Land of Israel]]. It became an umbrella organization of the pioneering [[Zionist youth movement]]s.
==History== HeHalutz was founded by Eliezer Joffe in America in 1905, and about the same time in [[Russia]].<ref>{{cite book | last1 = Ritov | first1 = Israel | first2 = Yehuda | last2 = Slutsky | chapter = He-Ḥalutz | title = Encyclopaedia Judaica | editor = Michael Berenbaum and Fred Skolnik | edition = 2 | volume = 8 | place = Detroit | publisher = Macmillan Reference USA | year = 2007 | pages = 756–761 | url = http://go.galegroup.com/ps/i.do?id=GALE%7CCX2587508655&v=2.1&u=imcpl1111&it=r&p=GVRL&sw=w&asid=377191611c4ffc8f4281aa4d532302f7}}</ref>
During [[World War I]], HeHalutz branches opened across Europe (including Russia), America and Canada. Leaders of the organization included [[Yitzhak Ben-Zvi]] (later the second president of the [[State of Israel]]), and [[David Ben-Gurion]] (later the first Prime Minister of Israel) in America, and [[Joseph Trumpeldor]] in Russia.
Ben-Gurion was living in [[Jerusalem]] at the start of the First World War, where he and Ben Zvi recruited forty Jews into a Jewish militia to assist the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] army. Despite this, he was deported to Egypt in March 1915. From there he made his way to the United States, where he remained for three years. On his arrival, he and Ben Zvi went on a tour of 35 cities in an attempt to raise a Hechalutz "pioneer army" of 10,000 men to fight on Turkey's side.<ref>Teveth, Shabtai (1985) ''Ben-Gurion and the Palestinian Arabs. From Peace to War.'' Oxford University Press. {{ISBN|0-19-503562-3}}. pp. 25, 26.</ref> After the [[Balfour Declaration of 1917|Balfour Declaration]] of November 1917, the situation changed dramatically and Ben-Gurion, with the interest of Zionism in mind, switched sides and joined the newly formed [[Jewish Legion]] of the [[British Army]], leaving to fight the Turks in Palestine.
At its peak, between 1930 and 1935, HeHalutz operated in 25 countries throughout Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Northern South America. In 1932-1934, [[Golda Meir]], later the prime minister of Israel, was the secretary of the women's chapter of HeHalutz in the United States.<ref>[http://www.jewishdestiny.com/destinys-projects/faith-fate/a-new-beginning/biographies/golda-meir/ Golda Meir]</ref>
In 1932, the organization established headquarters in New York and twenty branches in cities and towns throughout the United States and Canada. Farms were then established to train members for agricultural work in Palestine. Such farms operated in Creamridge, New Jersey, Heightstown, New Jersey, Poughkeepsie, New York, Smithville, Ontario., and Colton, California.<ref>[https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/judaica/ejud_0002_0008_0_08655.html Jewish Virtual Library: HeHalutz]</ref>
In 1933, after Jews were expelled from the workforce in Nazi Germany, HeHalutz farms became the primary framework for vocational training and preparation for emigration.<ref>[https://books.google.co.il/books?id=eKwyyGrTSvAC&pg=PA243&lpg=PA243&dq=hehalutz+farms&source=bl&ots=OsPHXXeAW8&sig=7D0044HkPtIwcfhXPXci-lzAF50&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiKmfn5xMzUAhXFXhoKHfnuAsMQ6AEIOTAE#v=onepage&q=hehalutz%20farms&f=true Before Catastrophe: The Distinctive Path of German Zionism, Hagit Lavsky]</ref>
By the eve of [[World War II|Second World War]] in 1939, HeHalutz numbered 100,000 members worldwide, with approximately 60,000 having already emigrated (''[[aliyah]]'') to [[Mandate Palestine]], and with 16,000 members in training centers (''[[Hakhshara|hakhsharot]]'') for the pioneering life in the [[Land of Israel]].<ref>[http://www.ushmm.org/wlc/article.php?lang=en&ModuleId=10007240 Resistance in the Smaller Ghettos of Eastern Europe] United States Holocaust Memorial Museum</ref> During the war and German occupation, Jews in some ghettos in Europe established Hechalutz units, as in Lithuania's [[Šiauliai Ghetto]].<ref name=ALJ>{{cite web |url=http://www.lithuanianjews.org.il/htmls/article_list4.aspx?C2014=14288&BSP=14059&BSS59=14055 |title=The Shavli Ghetto |publisher=Association of Lithuanian Jews in Israel |accessdate=27 April 2012}}</ref> By the 1950's HeHalutz"... was absorbed by [[Hashomer Hatzair]], which had always maintained a large degree of autonomy. Nominally, however, the He-Ḥalutz Organization of America still exists...."<ref>[https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/judaica/ejud_0002_0008_0_08655.html Jewish Virtual Library: HeHalutz]</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
:''This article incorporates text from the [[United States Holocaust Memorial Museum]], and has been released under the [[GFDL]].''

revision.comment: not a stub
revision.text:
{{Infobox Person | name = Henriette Mayer van den Bergh | image = Henriette Mayer van den Bergh - Van Lerius.jpg |caption = Wedding portrait of Henriette van den Bergh, aged 19, by [[Joseph van Lerius]] | birth_date = 1838 | death_date = 1920 | death_place = [[Antwerp]] | nationality = [[Belgium]] }} '''Henriëtte Mayer-van den Bergh''' (1838 – 1920) was a [[Belgium|Belgian]] museum founder, known for commissioning the building and establishing [[Museum Mayer van den Bergh]], which she curated until her death.
She was the daughter of the [[Antwerp]] senator Jean Félix Van den Bergh who ran the “La Cloche” brewery with his brother Maximilien.<ref name=erfgoed>[https://inventaris.onroerenderfgoed.be/erfgoedobjecten/5329 Hotel Mayer-van den Bergh] in erfgoed Vlaanderen</ref> Henriette married the Cologne businessman Emil Mayer in 1857, who had moved to Antwerp to open a franchise for his family's pharmacy and spice business.<ref name=erfgoed/> The Mayer-Van den Berghs purchased the 'Hof van Arenberg' on the corner of Lange Gasthuisstraat and Arenbergstraat in 1861 and renovated it to suit their taste.<ref name=erfgoed/> They had two sons, Fritz and Oscar. After the death of her husband Emil in 1879, Henriette withdrew from society but turned to the study of art. Her oldest son Fritz broke off his studies to move back in with her and Oscar took over the family business. In 1887 Fritz took her name, and in 1888 both sons were granted noble titles.<ref>[https://www.museummayervandenbergh.be/en/page/henri%C3%ABtte-van-den-bergh-fritz%E2%80%99s-mother Henriëtte van den Bergh, Fritz’s mother] on museum website</ref> Fritz became thereafter known in the art world as 'Chev. Mayer-van den Bergh'.
==Founding a museum== During the years her husband was alive, Henriette was probably already active as a collector, as the archives of her museum have provenance notes by her son Fritz indicating "Maman" for works purchased by her. After her son returned to live with her, he first spent time on his own numismatic collection and then turned his attention to cataloguing the family's art. In 1892, mother and son sold a large part of their collection, presumably to enable Fritz to make serious acquisitions with an eye for founding a museum. During the next nine years he became a dealer in his own right, making sales and purchases to augment his growing collection. After his untimely death, Henriette fulfilled his dream, hiring the architect Joseph Hertogs to build an adjacent building in Gothic style, and hiring advisors to help her oversee her son's estate, while securing his papers regarding the core collection that was destined for the museum. She curated the museum herself until she died, leaving a legacy that has survived to the present day.
==References== {{reflist}} * [http://www.tento.be/OKV-artikel/museum-mayer-van-den-bergh-antwerpen Museum Mayer van den Bergh] in 'Openbaar Kunstbezit Vlaanderen' {{Commons category|Henriëtte Mayer van den Bergh}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Bergh, Henriette Mayer van den}} [[Category:1838 births]] [[Category:1920 deaths]] [[Category:Philanthropists]] [[Category:Belgian women]] [[Category:Curators]] [[Category:Museum founders]]

page.title: History of early childhood care and education

revision.comment: -[[Category:Education]]; -[[Category:Educational stages]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
The '''History of early childhood care and education''' (ECCE) refers to the development of care and education of children between birth and eight years old throughout history. ECCE has a global scope, and caring for and educating young children has always been an integral part of human societies. Arrangements for fulfilling these societal roles have evolved over time and remain varied across cultures, often reflecting [[family]] and [[community]] structures as well as the social and economic roles of women and men.<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0014/001477/147794e.pdf|title=EFA Global Monitoring Report 2007: Strong Foundations - Early Childhood Care and Education|last=UNESCO|first=|publisher=Paris, UNESCO|year=2006|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> Historically, such arrangements have largely been informal, involving family, household and community members. The formalization of these arrangements emerged in the [[Nineteenth Century|nineteenth century]] with the establishment of [[kindergarten]]s for educational purposes and day nurseries for care in much of [[Europe]] and [[North America]], [[Brazil]], [[China]], [[India]], [[Jamaica]] and [[Mexico]].<ref name=":0">Kamerman, S. B. 2006. [https://olc.worldbank.org/sites/default/files/3-A_global_history_of_early_childhood_care_and_education_Background_paper_EFAGlobalMonitoringReport2007UNESCO_0.pdf A global history of early childhood education and care. Background paper for ''EFA Global Monitoring Report 2007''].</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0019/001913/191327e.pdf|title=Caring and Learning Together: A Case Study of Jamaica|last=Jones|first=J.|last2=Brown|first2=A.|last3=Brown|first3=J.|publisher=Paris, UNESCO|year=2011|isbn=|series=UNESCO Early Childhood and Family Policy Series, No. 21|location=|pages=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0018/001878/187884e.pdf|title=Caring and Learning Together: A Case Study of Brazil|last=Nunes|first=F.|last2=Corsino|first2=P.|last3=Didonet|first3=V.|publisher=Paris, UNESCO|year=2010|isbn=|series=UNESCO Early Childhood and Family Policy Series No. 19|location=|pages=}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite book|url=http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0023/002335/233558E.pdf|title=Investing against Evidence: The Global State of Early Childhood Care and Education|last=Marope|first=P.T.M.|last2=Kaga|first2=Y.|publisher=Paris, UNESCO|year=2015|isbn=978-92-3-100113-0|location=|pages=9–11}}</ref>
State-led expansion of ECCE services first emerged in the [[Russian Federation]] in the early twentieth century as part of the [[Socialism|socialist]] project to foster equal participation of women and men in production and in public life, and to publicly provide education from the youngest possible age.<ref>Taratukhina, M. S., Polyakova, M. N., Berezina, T. A., Notkina, N. A., Sheraizina, R. M., Borovkov, M. I. 2006. [http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0014/001491/149142e.pdf Early childhood care and education in the Russian Federation. Background paper for ''EFA Global Monitoring Report 2007''].</ref> This development extended to socialist or former socialist countries such as [[Cambodia]], China and [[Vietnam|Viet Nam]].<ref>Haddad, L. 2002. [http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0012/001279/127983e.pdf An Integrated Approach to Early Childhood Education and Care]. UNESCO Early Childhood and Family Policy Series, No. 3. Paris, UNESCO.</ref> [[France]] was another early starter having integrated [[Preschool|pre-school]] into its education system as early as 1886 and expanded its provision in the 1950s.<ref name=":0" /> In real terms, the significant expansion of ECCE services began in the 1960s with the considerable growth in women's participation in the [[Labour Market|labour market]] and extensive developments in child and family policies in Europe and the [[United States|United States of America]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
== ECCE development in 1990s == The 1990s opened a new page in the history of the development of ECCE catalysed mainly by the rapid and successive ratification of the 1989 [[United Nations]] [[Convention on the Rights of the Child]] (CRC). By its explicit mention of 'the child' – meaning every human being under the age of eighteen or majority – the CRC reinforced the 1960 [[UNESCO]] [[Convention and Recommendation against Discrimination in Education]] which should have covered young children in any case. With its moral force and near universal ratification, the CRC formally recognized children as holders of rights to survival and development, to be heard and to participate in decisions affecting them in accordance with their evolving capacities with their best interests and non-discrimination as overarching principles. While the CRC in Article 18 also recognizes the primary role of parents and legal guardians in the upbringing and development of children, it obliges States Parties to help them carry out these duties.<ref name=":1" />
The second boost to the development of ECCE was the adoption of the World Declaration on [[Education For All|Education for All]] (EFA) in March 1990 in [[Jomtien Beach|Jomtien, Thailand]]. Reflecting General Comment 7, the Jomtien Declaration explicitly stated that 'learning begins at birth', and called for 'early childhood care and initial education' (Article 5). This novel recognition of ECCE as an integral part of basic education featured again in the major goals adopted at the 1990 UN World Summit for Children. Ten years later, in 2000, this expanded vision of basic education was rearmed in the Dakar Framework for Action on EFA, adopted at the World Education Forum as the first of the six EFA goals: 'Expanding and improving comprehensive ECCE especially for the most vulnerable and disadvantaged children'. Regrettably, unlike other EFA goals, this was stated as a broad and aspirational goal without numerical targets or clear benchmarks.<ref name=":1" />
== ECCE Development in the 21st century == ECCE was further reinforced by the [[Millennium Development Goals]] (MDGs), albeit only partially. Adopted at the UN Millennium Summit in 2000, two of the MDGs had direct relevance to early childhood development: (i) improving [[maternal health]], with the targets of reducing the [[Maternal death|maternal mortality]] rates by three-quarters and providing universal access to [[reproductive health]] (MDG4), and (ii) reducing the [[Child mortality|under-five mortality]] rate by two-thirds between 1990 and 2015 (MDG5). Thus, the child and maternal health aspects of ECCE became part and parcel of a global 'effort to meet the needs of the [[Poverty threshold|world's poorest]]' while childcare and early education aspects were left out.
In recent decades, ECCE has further received attention from diverse stakeholders including research communities, [[civil society]] and [[intergovernmental organization]]s which furthered understanding of its holistic and multisectoral nature. Research continues to document the multifaceted development benefits of ECCE for health, education, social and [[emotional well-being]], [[social equity]] and cohesion, the economy, employment and earnings.<ref name=":1" />
== See also == * [[History of education]] * [[History of childhood]] * [[Right to education]] * [[Social history#History of education]]
== Sources ==
{{Free-content attribution | title = Investing against Evidence: The Global State of Early Childhood Care and Education | author = Marope, P.T.M., Kaga, Y. | publisher = UNESCO | page numbers = 9-11 | source = UNESCO | documentURL = http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0023/002335/233558E.pdf | license statement URL = http://www.unesco.org/ulis/cgi-bin/ulis.pl?catno=233558&set=0058CBADEE_0_390&gp=1&lin=1&ll=1 | license = CC-BY-SA IGO 3.0 }}
==External links== * {{cite web|url=http://www.worldomep.org/|title=World Organization for Early Childhood Education (OMEP)}} * {{cite web|url=http://nieer.org/|title=National Institute for Early Education Research}} * {{cite web|url=http://www.nea.org/home/18163.htm|title=Early Childhood Education|publisher=National Education Association}} * {{cite web|url=http://heckmanequation.org|title=Heckman Equation for Investing in Early Human Development}}

revision.comment: Rescued 1 archive link; remove 1 link. [[User:GreenC/WaybackMedic_2.1|Wayback Medic 2.1]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox organization | name = Institute for Dynamic Educational Advancement | logo = | type = Non-Profit Organization | founded_date = 1998 | founder = Michael Douma | origins = Rockville, MD | key_people = | area_served = | focus = mobile apps, education | method = | revenue = | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = | num_members = | owner = | Non-profit_slogan = Fresh ideas to advance scientific and cultural literacy. | homepage = http://www.idea.org/ | dissolved = | footnotes = }}
The '''Institute for Dynamic Educational Advancement''' (IDEA.org) is a U.S.-based nonprofit organization working in the area of scientific and cultural literacy. The organization was established in 1998 and incorporated in 2002, and has collaborated with museums, schools, nonprofit organizations, and public service projects.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www2.guidestar.org/ReportNonProfit.aspx?ein=01-0702612|title=GuideStar Exchange Reports for Institute For Dynamic Education Advancement Inc|work=guidestar.org}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://lii.org/cs/lii/view/item/27964|title=ipl2: Information You Can Trust|author=ipl2|work=lii.org}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://foundationcenter.org/pnd/ontheweb/otw.jhtml?id=263800010|title=Institute for Dynamic Educational Advancement|author=Foundation Center|work=Philanthropy News Digest (PND)}}</ref>
==Activities== * '''[[WebExhibits]]''' "virtual museum" – in 1999, IDEA founded the [[WebExhibits]] [[virtual museum]], an interactive, [[virtual museum]] of science, humanities, and culture that uses information, virtual experiments, and hands-on activities that prompt visitors to think, to formulate questions, and to explore topics from a variety of angles. IDEA published research on exhibit design and usability, and advocated for the format as an effective approach to draw in visitors to complex, multidisciplinary topics. * '''[[SpicyNodes]]''' - is a presentation method for visually browsing hierarchical information, similar to [[concept mapping]]. Several implementations of SpicyNodes have been developed by IDEA, including a web-based version built on [[Adobe Flash]] which is available as a [[Software as a service]] web site with [[Freemium|both free and paid]] versions; and as [[multitouch]] version for the [[iPad]] released in Spring 2011 as part of the "WikiNodes" app. The web-based implementation received a "Best Website for Teaching and Learning" award in 2011 from [[American Association of School Librarians| American Association of School Librarians (AASL)]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ala.org/ala/mgrps/divs/aasl/guidelinesandstandards/bestlist/bestwebsitestop25.cfm|title=Best Websites for Teaching & Learning 2013|work=ala.org|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713093151/http://www.ala.org/ala/mgrps/divs/aasl/guidelinesandstandards/bestlist/bestwebsitestop25.cfm|archivedate=2011-07-13|df=}}</ref> and was voted #edchat's 35 Best Web 2.0 Classroom Tools in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://edudemic.com/2010/07/the-35-best-web-2-0-classroom-tools-chosen-by-you/|title=The 35 Best Web 2.0 Classroom Tools Chosen By You|work=edudemic.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100827104013/http://edudemic.com/2010/07/the-35-best-web-2-0-classroom-tools-chosen-by-you/|archivedate=2010-08-27|df=}}</ref> It has been a subject of instruction in several schools.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cs.ucdavis.edu/~ma/ECS272/readings.html|title=Winter 2010 -- ECS272|work=ucdavis.edu}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wpi.edu/Academics/Library/Help/Courses/HU3900/HU3900tools.html|title=Gordon Library: Ask Us - WPI|work=wpi.edu|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080720155502/http://www.wpi.edu/Academics/Library/Help/Courses/HU3900/HU3900tools.html|archivedate=2008-07-20|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://innovations.oise.utoronto.ca/edtech/index.php/Spicynodes |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-05-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720235327/http://innovations.oise.utoronto.ca/edtech/index.php/Spicynodes |archivedate=2011-07-20 |df= }}</ref><ref> http://educationaltechnologyguy.blogspot.com/2011/03/spicynodes-visualize-and-organize.html</ref><ref> http://mashe.hawksey.info/2010/11/entice-with-a-bit-of-spice-spicynodes-mind-mapping-and-visualisation-tool/</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://teachnologist.info/?p=632 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-05-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110830141230/http://teachnologist.info/?p=632 |archivedate=2011-08-30 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://eatoneducationalinsights.edublogs.org/2010/11/09/spicy-nodes-online-graphic-organizer/|title=The Teachers' Tech Lounge » Blog Archive » Spicy Nodes Online Graphic Organizer|work=edublogs.org}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rwc.uc.edu/ltc/teach_strategies.html|title=404, University of Cincinnati, located in Cincinnati, Ohio., University of Cincinnati|work=University of Cincinnati}}</ref>
The product is used in a broad number of disciplines,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spicynodes.org/gallery-recent.html|title=Spicynodes|work=spicynodes.org}}</ref> and has an [[open API]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.programmableweb.com/api/spicynodes|title=Spicynodes|work=ProgrammableWeb}}</ref> allowing developers to use it for visualization tasks as well as to create [[Mashup (web application hybrid)|mashups]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spicynodes.org/developers-mashup-SN_and_maps.html|title=Spicynodes : Create a Mashup Between SpicyNodes and Google Maps|work=spicynodes.org}}</ref>
* '''[[WikiNodes]]''' - is an app for the [[Apple Inc.|Apple]] [[iPad]] which uses the [[SpicyNodes]] visualization method. It is the first tablet app for browsing Wikipedia using a [[radial tree]] approach to visualize how articles and subsections of articles are interrelated. ([[Wikipedia:Wikipedia Signpost/2011-06-13/In the news|Wikipedia's 'The Signpost']], 13 June 2011) * '''ColoRotate''' - is a project started in January 2006 to explain to the public, students, and graphic professionals the three-dimensional nature of [[color vision]] in the eye and mind. It is related to the color-related exhibits in the WebExhibit museum. It consists of a 3D [[color space]] within which users can see color points, and manipulate them. There are several implementations of the ColoRotate approach, including a free web site, a Photoshop plugin, a web widget, and an iPad app.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.appappeal.com/app/colorotate/|title=ColoRotate|work=appappeal.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://downloadsquad.switched.com/2009/05/15/colorotate-3d-color-palette-creator-and-cs4-plugin/|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120707215742/http://downloadsquad.switched.com/2009/05/15/colorotate-3d-color-palette-creator-and-cs4-plugin/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2012-07-07|title=Engadget - Technology News, Advice and Features|work=Engadget}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://singlefunction.com/colorotateorg/|title=ColoRotate.org|work=singlefunction.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://photo.it-enquirer.com/2010/03/21/colorotate-a-colour-picker-based-on-human-perception-of-colours/|title=ColoRotate, a colour picker based on human perception of colours|author=Erik Vlietinck|work=IT Enquirer|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111110223333/http://photo.it-enquirer.com/2010/03/21/colorotate-a-colour-picker-based-on-human-perception-of-colours/|archivedate=2011-11-10|df=}}</ref><ref>magazine. Print.</ref><ref>Gates, Stephen. "ColoRotate http://blog.stephengates.com/2009/06/18/colorotate-rethinking-the-color-picker/</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://scienceblogs.com/bioephemera/2010/02/colorotate_a_new_interface_for.php|title=ColoRotate: A new interface for picking color palettes|work=bioephemera|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100211002851/http://scienceblogs.com/bioephemera/2010/02/colorotate_a_new_interface_for.php|archivedate=2010-02-11|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://lis.luther.edu/node/3871 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-07-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111008003442/http://lis.luther.edu/node/3871 |archivedate=2011-10-08 |df= }}</ref> * '''Research''' - via its [[SpicyNodes]] project, IDEA researched ways for the public to author and use [[Radial tree|radial maps]] to display hierarchical information.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.archimuse.com/mw2010/papers/douma/douma.html|title=Archives & Museum Informatics: Museums and the Web 2010: Papers: Douma, M. et al., Concept Maps for On-line Exhibits: Using SpicyNodes|work=archimuse.com}}</ref><ref>SpicyNodes Radial Map Engine Douma, M.; Ligierko, G.; Angelov, I. APPLICATIONS OF MATHEMATICS IN ENGINEERING AND ECONOMICS: Proceedings of the 34th Conference on Applications of Mathematics in Engineering and Economics (AMEE '08). AIP Conference Proceedings, Volume 1067, pp. 209-220 (2008).</ref> IDEA sponsored a 2008 study on how people find information, which was widely cited in the blogosphere.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://conference.archimuse.com/blog/ngamble/new_study_factors_improve_online_experiences |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-05-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081026010233/http://conference.archimuse.com/blog/ngamble/new_study_factors_improve_online_experiences |archivedate=2008-10-26 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://educationload.com/?p=11http://www.peoplepoints.co.nz/2008/08/idea-factors-that-imporve-online.htmlwww.idea.org/find-information.pdf|title=educationload.com|work=educationload.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gryphonmountain.net/archives/techcomm/results-of-a-study-about-online-experience|title=Gryphon Mountain - Just another WordPress weblog|work=gryphonmountain.net}}</ref> The key finding was the designers and communication directors overestimate the ease with which users can find information online, and they tend to underestimate the value of basic qualities like current information and engaging writing. Additionally, IDEA researched culturally appropriate ways to collect information from diverse populations. IDEA has collaborated with cancer researchers to make prostate cancer prognosis tools available to the general public,<ref>DE Soto, S Glaser, RH Roberts, MJ Schipper, PW, "Impact of Common Iliac Nodal Treatment on Radiation Outcomes in Localized Prostate Cancer". Urology, 2008.</ref> and to bridge the gap of underserved, Native American communities dealing with cancer.<ref>UICC World Cancer Congress 2006 Bridging the Gap: Transforming Knowledge into Action July 8–12, 2006, Washington, DC, USA</ref>
==See also== * [[Virtual museum]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
