{{Infobox school |name = Nauru Secondary School |image = |alt = |caption = |established = |type = [[Secondary school]] |affiliation = [[Government of Nauru]] |principal = |colors = |uniform = |location = [[Yaren District]] |country = [[Nauru]] | coordinates = {{Coord|-0.5462412999999999|166.91550819999998|display=inline,title}} | pushpin_map = Nauru }} [[File:A classroom at Nauru Secondary School after receiving its $11 million Australian-funded refurbishment, April 2010. Photo- DFAT (12045836243).jpg|thumb|A classroom at Nauru Secondary School after refurbishment as part of an [[Australia–Nauru relations|Australian aid package to the island state]].]] '''Nauru Secondary School''' ('''NSS''') is an upper secondary school in [[Yaren District]], [[Nauru]], located in the Nauru Learning Village, along with the [[University of the South Pacific]] Nauru Campus and the Nauru Technical & Vocational Education Training Centre.<ref>"[https://www.usp.ac.fj/news/story.php?id=2781 USP opens new Nauru Campus]." [[University of the South Pacific]]. Retrieved on June 5, 2018.</ref> It serves years 10-12 and has the final stages of secondary education in Nauru.<ref>[http://docstore.ohchr.org/SelfServices/FilesHandler.ashx?enc=6QkG1d/PPRiCAqhKb7yhsqMFgv33OTgoZv7ZAgL6thBs%2BJaDouDrmbrhkSKQnAJmPZ9UvJeFASCaHOYMWlSYYCuENbqZ7%2B4S5kzfEKujpCmbACo3%2BCb5LwxaXyHF2qjW Document by the]." [[OHCHR]]. Retrieved on 8 July 2018. "[...]and finally Nauru Secondary School (Years 10-12) where compulsory education end at Year 12."</ref> {{Asof|2002}} it served years 8 through 12.<ref>Brandjes, Denis (preparer). "[http://oasis.col.org/bitstream/handle/11599/235/SchoolnetPacific.pdf?sequence=1&isAllowed=y Page 1 THE COMMONWEALTH OF LEARNING School Networking in the Pacific Island States An Environmental Scan and Plan for the Establishment of Schoolnets for the Pacific Island States]." April 2002. p. 49 (PDF p. 51).</ref> It uses the curriculum of [[Queensland]], [[Australia]].<ref name=EQI>"[https://eqi.com.au/studyoptions/offshore/Pages/teachers-for-nauru.aspx Teachers for Nauru]." [[Queensland Government]]. Retrieved on July 5, 2018.</ref>
In the 1950s it served forms 4 and 5, and a new building opened in 1954. Reuben Kun, who wrote an article about Nauru's university system, stated that in that period there was an unanticipated increase in the number of students at the school.<ref>Kun, Reuben. "Nauru." In: Crocombe, R. G. and Malama Meleisea (editors). ''Pacific Universities: Achievements, Problems, Prospects''. Institute of Pacific Studies, [[University of the South Pacific]], 1988. {{ISBN|9820200393}}, 9789820200395. p. [https://books.google.ca/books?id=GELtopSlvCEC&pg=PA309 309].</ref> The school had classes teaching [[Nauruan language|Nauruan]] circa the 1960s and 1970s.<ref>Barker, Xavier. "English Language as Bully in the Republic of Nauru." In: Rapatahana, Vaughan and Pauline Bunce (editors). ''English Language as Hydra: Its Impacts on Non-English Language Cultures'' (Volume 9 of Linguistic Diversity and Language Rights). [[Multilingual Matters]], June 22, 2012. {{ISBN|184769750X}}, 9781847697509. Start: p. [https://books.google.ca/books?id=lTbnLSyaX5sC&pg=PA18 18]. CITED: p. [https://books.google.ca/books?id=lTbnLSyaX5sC&pg=PA28 28].</ref> In 2013 it became a Queensland Recognised School.<ref name=EQI/>
Nauru Secondary has a library.<ref>''Book Provision in the Pacific Islands''. [[UNESCO]] Pacific States Office, 1999. {{ISBN|9820201551}}, 9789820201552. p. [https://books.google.ca/books?id=1k1HbbMRI_4C&pg=PA33&lpg=PA33 33].</ref>
==See also== * [[Education in Nauru]]
==References== {{reflist}} {{Nauru topics}} [[Category:High schools]] [[Category:Schools in Oceania]] [[Category:Education in Nauru]] {{school-stub}}

'''Nisreen El-Hashemite''' (full name and title: HRH Princess Dr. Nisreen Bint Prince Mohammed Bin King Faisal (I) Bin El-Sharif Hussein El-Hashemite<ref name="bio"/>) is an [[Iraqis|Iraqi]] scientist and activist, active particularly in the promotion of women in science, and women's health and development.
== Biography == Born in Kuwait,<ref name="peak">A. Loh, [https://thepeakmagazine.com.sg/interviews/meet-dr-nisreen-el-hashemite-iraqi-princess-overturned-convention-pursue-medicine/ 'Meet Dr Nisreen El-Hashemite, the Iraqi princess who overturned convention to pursue medicine'] (12/05/17) on The Peak</ref> graduated in Biomedical Sciences and is a doctor in [[human genetics]].<ref name="bio">RASIT, [http://whforum.rasit.org/founderbio.html Founder's Bio]</ref> She worked at [[University College London]], where she developed a technique to diagnose [[genetic disorder]]s, and at [[Harvard Medical School]], where she investigated [[tuberous sclerosis]].<ref>Andrea M. Rosa del Pino, [https://www.elmundo.es/loc/2017/05/16/591b3468268e3e69398b4889.html 'Nisreen, the princess who works (and really) to help others'] (16/05/17) on ''[[El Mundo (Spain)|El Mundo]]''</ref> In 2007 she left her scientific career to devote herself to promoting science, technology and medicine through the [[Royal Academy of Science International Trust]] (RASIT), of which she is its [[executive director]].<ref name="bio"/> She tried to establish an institute of medicine and [[public health]] in the [[Middle East]] and has worked in providing assistance to minors and women.
Founder and president of the [[Women in Science International League]], she is an active advocate for [[Women in STEM fields|gender equality in science]]; in that sense, she was associated with the [[United Nations|UN]]'s sustainability agenda, where she works towards the inclusion of female talents in science. As part of this work, in 2015 she presented a resolution to the United Nations that declared February 11 as [[International Women's and Girl's Day in Science]],<ref>J. Wapner, [https://www.newsweek.com/islam-science-women-557937 'Using the Words of Islam, an Iraqi Princess Fights for Women in Science'] (17/02/17) on [[Newsweek]]</ref> in recognition of the role played by women in the world, science and technology.<ref name="peak"/><ref>UN, [http://www.un.org/es/events/women-and-girls-in-science-day/background.shtml 'Día Internacional de la Mujer y la Niña en la Ciencia, 11 de febrero']</ref>
El-Hashemite established the UN's [[World Women's Health and Development Forum]]. She 'is founder of [[MUTE International Program]], to promote, protect and ensure equal [[human rights]] for the [[Hearing loss|deaf and hearing-impaired]]; and a co-founder of [[Culture for Peace Program]], to promote peace through arts'.<ref name="MAC"/>
In 2017 she received the Muhammad Ali Humanitarian of the Year Award.<ref name="MAC">[[Muhammad Ali Center]], [https://alicenter.org/fifth-annual-muhammad-ali-humanitarian-awardees-announced-hrh-princess-dr-nisreen-el-hashemite-patricia-arquette-ashley-judd-hill-harper-paige-elenson-among-honorees-presenters-names-also-relea/ 'Fifth annual Muhammad Ali Humanitarian awardees announced'] (30/08/17)</ref>
She part of the Iraqi royal family — her grandfather, [[Faysal I]], was the first king of modern [[Iraq]]<ref>Saheli Roy Choudhury, [https://www.cnbc.com/2017/03/13/nisreen-el-hashemite-on-promoting-women-in-science.html 'This Iraqi princess wants more women to become scientists and help make the world sustainable'] (13/03/17) on [[CNBC]]</ref> — and is a direct descendant of [[Muhammad]], the founder of Islam.<ref name="MAC"/> {{UN-stub}} == References ==

revision.text:
{{David Cameron sidebar}} {{Use British English|date=December 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2015}} [[File:Lord Ashcroft presents Zulu at the Policy Exchange-Crossbench Film Society cropped.JPG|thumb|Michael Ashcroft]]
"'''Piggate'''" refers to an uncorroborated anecdote that during his university years former [[British prime minister]] [[David Cameron]] put a "private part of his anatomy" into a dead pig's mouth as part of an [[hazing|initiation ceremony]] for the [[Piers Gaveston Society]]. The anecdote was reported by [[Michael Ashcroft]] and [[Isabel Oakeshott]] in their unauthorised biography of Cameron, ''[[Call Me Dave]]'', attributing the story to an anonymous Member of Parliament who was a "distinguished Oxford contemporary" of Cameron's. Extracts from the book were published in the ''[[Daily Mail]]'' on 21 September 2015, prior to its publication.
[[Downing Street]] sources responded by saying that Cameron would not dignify the anecdote with a response while friends reported him saying that it was "utter nonsense". Cameron said later that "a very specific denial was made a week ago".
Ashcroft and Oakeshott failed to receive a response from the purported owner of a photograph of the alleged incident, and since the extract's publication no corroborating evidence has as yet been produced to support the anecdote.
In an interview, [[Jonathan Guinness, 3rd Baron Moyne#Children|Valentine Guinness]], one of the [[Piers Gaveston Society]] founders, said that Cameron "may well have attended one of their parties" but as far as he knew he was never a member.
==Anecdote== It was alleged that, as a student at [[University of Oxford|Oxford University]], former [[British prime minister]] [[David Cameron]] inserted "a private part of his anatomy" into the mouth of a dead pig, as part of an initiation ceremony for the [[Piers Gaveston Society]]. The pig's head is said to have been resting on the lap of another society member during the act.<ref name="mail"/>
In their unauthorised biography of Cameron, ''[[Call Me Dave]]'', [[Michael Ashcroft]] and [[Isabel Oakeshott]] recount that a [[Member of Parliament]] and "distinguished Oxford contemporary" told the anecdote "out of the blue" at a business dinner in June 2014. They initially assumed the statement to be a joke, but the MP repeated the anecdote some weeks later, and for a third time with more detail some months after that. The MP claimed to have seen photographic evidence of the event, describing the dimensions of the alleged photograph and naming an individual who he claimed now possessed the image.<ref name="mail"/>
Ashcroft and Oakeshott failed to receive a response from the purported owner of a photograph of the alleged incident, and since the extract's publication no corroborating evidence has as yet been produced to support the anecdote. In their book, Ashcroft and Oakeshott comment that "Perhaps it is a case of mistaken identity. Yet it is an elaborate story for an otherwise credible figure to invent."<ref name="mail">{{cite news | url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3242504/Drugs-debauchery-making-extraordinary-Prime-Minister-years-rumours-dogged-truth-shockingly-decadent-Oxford-days-gifted-Bullingdon-boy.html | title=Drugs, debauchery and the making of an extraordinary Prime Minister | work=Daily Mail |location=London | date=20 September 2015 | accessdate=25 September 2015 | author=Michael Ashcroft and Isabel Oakeshott}}</ref> Speaking to ''[[Channel 4 News]]'' in September 2015, Oakeshott said: "We couldn’t get to the bottom of that source’s allegations ... So we merely reported the account that the source gave us … We don’t say whether we believe it to be true".<ref name="GuardianVinerJuly2016">{{cite news |last=Viner|first=Katharine|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/jul/12/how-technology-disrupted-the-truth | title=How technology disrupted the truth | work=The Guardian | location=London | date=12 July 2016 | accessdate=18 July 2016}}</ref><ref name="Channel4YouTube">{{cite news | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rm_Bli5h0Ns | title=David Cameron allegations: Toby Young vs Isabel Oakeshott | work=Channel 4 News | location=London | date=21 September 2015 | accessdate=18 July 2016 | author=Channel 4 News}}</ref> Speaking at the [[Cheltenham Literature Festival]] in October 2015, Oakeshott said that the source of the allegation "could have been slightly deranged" and said that "there is no need for burden of proof on a colourful anecdote where we’re quite upfront about our own reservations about whether to take it seriously".<ref name="oakeshottsqueal">{{cite news |title =Isabel Oakeshott runs squealing from David Cameron #piggate claims |newspaper =[[The Guardian]] |location =London |date =9 October 2015 |url =https://www.theguardian.com/media/mediamonkeyblog/2015/oct/09/isabel-oakeshott-david-cameron-piggatecall-me-dave |accessdate=11 October 2015}}</ref>
The anecdote first came to public attention when extracts from the book were published in the ''[[Daily Mail]]'' on 20 September 2015, prior to its publication.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/sep/21/david-cameron-pig-head-lord-ashcroft-unofficial-biography-drug-taking-claims|title=Cameron biography: Ashcroft makes new debauchery claims about student days|work=The Guardian|location=London|accessdate=21 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/david-cameron/11879859/David-Cameron-claims-Five-things-you-need-to-know.html|title=David Cameron claims: Five things you need to know|work=The Daily Telegraph|location=London|accessdate=21 September 2015}}</ref>
==Background== Lord Ashcroft had long been a supporter of the British [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] and was its biggest donor, having donated around £10 million, before dropping his support for the party in 2013 due to conflicts with David Cameron, especially his refusal to give Ashcroft a senior role in government despite his donations.<ref>{{cite news|title=Lord Ashcroft's Cameron biography bears hallmarks of revenge job|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/sep/21/lord-ashcrofts-cameron-biography-bears-hallmarks-of-revenge-job|accessdate=22 September 2015|work=The Guardian|location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://time.com/4043311/david-cameron-pig-gate-scandal/|title=Why David Cameron’s 'Pig-Gate' Scandal Isn't Going Away|work=TIME|accessdate=21 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2283926/Lord-Ashcroft-Drops-support-Tories-David-Camerons-gay-marriage-obsession.html|title=I'M still a Tory... but I wonder if Cameron is: Top donor Ashcroft drops his support for the party over PM's gay marriage 'obsession'|work=Daily Mail|location=London|accessdate=21 September 2015}}</ref> Some commentators have interpreted the pig story and other anecdotes in the book as Ashcroft's revenge and reignition of the feud.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.spectator.co.uk/steerpike/2015/09/lord-ashcroft-gets-his-revenge-on-david-cameron-piggate/ |title=Lord Ashcroft gets his revenge on David Cameron: #piggate|work=The Spectator|accessdate=21 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/11878948/Lord-Ashcroft-reignites-bitter-feud-with-David-Cameron.html|title=Lord Ashcroft reignites bitter feud with David Cameron|work=The Daily Telegraph|location=London|accessdate=21 September 2015}}</ref>
==Response== After being asked about the anecdote, Downing Street said that it would not "dignify" the claim with a response.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/george-osborne-refuses-to-comment-on-claims-that-david-cameron-put-his-genitals-in-a-dead-pigs-mouth-at-university-10510692.html|title=David Cameron says he 'will not dignify' claims he put his genitals in the mouth of a dead pig|work=The Independent|location=London|accessdate=25 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/downing-street-stays-silent-over-claims-david-cameron-put-genitals-in-a-dead-pigs-mouth-while-at-oxford-university-10510500.html|title=Downing Street stays silent over claims David Cameron put genitals in a dead pig's mouth while at Oxford University|work=The Independent|location=London|accessdate=21 September 2015}}</ref> ''[[The Independent]]'' reported that Cameron had told friends the claim was "utter nonsense".<ref name="The Independent">{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/dead-pig-allegations-are-utter-nonsense-david-cameron-tells-friends-10511399.html|title=Dead pig allegations are 'utter nonsense,' David Cameron tells friends|work=The Independent|location=London|date=21 September 2015|accessdate=25 September 2015}}</ref> Cameron did not post a tweet on his [[Twitter]] account until 23 September, whereupon he received a barrage of pig-sex-related replies.<ref name="nsubuga">{{cite news|url=http://metro.co.uk/2015/09/24/david-cameron-tweeted-for-the-first-time-since-piggate-and-it-didnt-go-very-well-5405621/|title=David Cameron tweeted for the first time since #piggate and it didn’t go very well|work=Metro|author=Jimmy Nsubuga|date=24 September 2015}}</ref><ref name="allegretti">{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2015/09/23/david-cameron-piggate_n_8184162.html|title=David Cameron Given Searing Reaction By Twitter Users After First Post Since #Piggate|work=The Huffington Post UK|author=Aubrey Allegretti|date=23 September 2015}}</ref>
Cameron joked about the situation during a talk in Oxford later that week, stating "I've had an interesting week. It's a week in which thousands of trees have died in vain, sales of [[Supertramp]] albums have gone through the roof and one man's reputation lies in ruins. I don't think Michael Ashcroft will ever recover."<ref name="BBC News">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-34363685|title=David Cameron jokes about Lord Ashcroft's book|date=25 September 2015|work=BBC News}}</ref> Six days after the story broke, Cameron responded to a question about the issue saying: "Everyone can see why the book was written and everyone can see straight through it. As for the specific issue raised, a very specific denial was made a week ago and I've nothing to add to that."<ref name="guardian27">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/sep/27/david-cameron-denies-lord-ashcroft-allegations-call-me-dave-dead-pig|title=David Cameron publicly denies Lord Ashcroft pig allegation for first time|work=The Guardian|location=London|date=27 September 2015|accessdate=28 September 2015}}</ref> At the time of the statement, Downing Street had made no on-the-record denial of the anecdote.<ref name="guardian27"/> Cameron also stated that he was deferring taking action at the present time to sue Ashcroft over the allegations because he was "too busy running the country".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.sky.com/story/1559948/pm-says-hes-too-busy-to-sue-lord-ashcroft |title=PM Says He's 'Too Busy' To Sue Lord Ashcroft |work=Sky News |date=28 September 2015}}</ref>
With the specific detail that the source of the story was a contemporary of Cameron's at Oxford, speculation mounted about which of the limited number of candidates could be the source of the story. [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] vice-chairman and former MP [[Mark Field]] was initially suspected within his own party as having been the source of the anecdote due to having briefed the co-author Isabel Oakeshott. Government sources accused Field of fabricating the anecdote as a part of a leadership plot, an allegation he furiously denied.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Owen|first1=Glen|title='I'm no porkie pie teller,' says MP named as 'Pig-gate' suspect as he vows to track down those who accused him|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3250491/I-m-no-porkie-pie-teller-says-MP-named-Pig-gate-suspect-vows-track-accused-him.html|accessdate=6 October 2015|date=27 September 2015}}</ref> Other MPs would go on to deny being the source including [[Boris Johnson]] and [[Ed Vaizey]] as Downing Street announced the launch of an investigation into the identity of the MP in question.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Newton Dunn|first1=Tom|title=Downing Street launches ‘Ham Cam’ probe|url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/news/politics/6652876/Downing-Street-probe-to-find-source-of-sex-act-claim.html|accessdate=6 October 2015|date=22 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Ashton|first1=Emily|url=https://twitter.com/elashton/status/645903356385472512|accessdate=6 October 2015|date=21 September 2015|title=MPs deny they are piggate source}}</ref>
Valentine Guinness, one of the founders of the Piers Gaveston Society, was quoted by journalist [[Toby Young]] as saying that although David Cameron "may well have attended one of their parties", as far as he knew Cameron "was never a member of the Piers Gaveston Society", so would not have taken part in such an initiation ceremony. Guinness called the story "purely malicious gossip".<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://blogs.spectator.co.uk/coffeehouse/2015/09/is-that-really-the-best-lord-ashcroft-could-dig-up/ |title=Is that really the best Lord Ashcroft could dig up? |work=The Spectator |date=21 September 2015}}</ref> Young and Cameron attended Oxford together.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2009/sep/27/toby-young-boris-johnson-cameron|title=When Boris Johnson met Dave Cameron|author=ToYoung|work=the Guardian}}</ref>
On 21 September 2015, James Kirkup in ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' wrote, "Toby Young, a Telegraph writer, [...] has investigated Mr Cameron’s university antics and found no evidence of the pig incident. 'I think it’s a figment of someone’s imagination,' he says."<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/david-cameron/11880588/A-pig-some-drugs-and-a-disappointed-billionaire-the-life-of-David-Cameron.html A pig, some drugs and a disappointed billionaire: the life of David Cameron] James Kirkup, ''The Daily Telegraph'' (London), 21 September 2015</ref>
==Reactions== Within minutes of the ''Daily Mail'' posting an article about the anecdote, #piggate, #snoutrage and #hameron<ref name="guardian1">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/sep/21/piggate-hameron-twitter-react-david-cameron-pig-head-claims|title=From #piggate to #Hameron: how Twitter reacted to David Cameron claims|work=The Guardian|location=London|accessdate=23 September 2015}}</ref> became [[trending topic]]s on Twitter.<ref name="guardian1"/> The "Piggate" name was quickly accepted by the media reporting on it<ref>{{cite web|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2015/09/21/what-piggate-really-says-about-the-state-of-british-politics/|title=What #PigGate Really Says About the State of British Politics|work=Foreign Policy|accessdate=23 September 2015}}</ref> (scandals are often given a name [[List of scandals with "-gate" suffix|suffixed with "-gate"]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://public.oed.com/aspects-of-english/english-in-use/the-gate-suffix/ |title=The ‘gate’ suffix |work=[[Oxford English Dictionary]]}}</ref>). This example of [[social media]] distraction was so great that there were concerns from some employers about the impact on workplace productivity.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Sheffield|first1=Hazel|title=David Cameron pig allegations could harm UK productivity|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/david-cameron-pig-allegations-could-harm-uk-productivity-10511347.html|accessdate=27 September 2015|work=The Independent|location=London|date=21 September 2015}}</ref>
After the anecdote appeared, social media users quickly made connections to "[[The National Anthem (Black Mirror)|The National Anthem]]", an episode of ''[[Black Mirror]]'' wherein a fictional Prime Minister has sex with a pig under duress. Series creator [[Charlie Brooker]], who wrote the episode, quickly denied any prior knowledge of the allegations, calling the situation "a complete coincidence, albeit a quite bizarre one."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.vox.com/2015/9/21/9365507/piggate-david-cameron-piers-galverston|title=9 questions about David Cameron's #PigGate you were too embarrassed to ask|work=Vox|accessdate=21 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/shortcuts/2015/sep/21/pigs-prime-minister-black-mirror-ashcroft-allegation-charlie-brooker|title=Charlie Brooker on Cameron and #piggate: 'I'd have been screaming it into traffic if I'd known'|work=The Guardian|location=London|accessdate=21 September 2015}}</ref>
[[Suzanne Moore]] in ''[[The Guardian]]'' compared the incident to the story related by [[Hunter S. Thompson]] on [[Lyndon B. Johnson]]'s campaign tactics early in his political career. Johnson supposedly planned to spread a fabricated story that his opponent had a penchant for "[[carnal knowledge]] of his own barnyard sows". Although the story was unbelievable, Johnson's purpose, according to Thompson, was to force his opponent to discuss it even in a refutation: "But let's make the sonofabitch ''deny'' it."<ref>{{Cite news |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |author=Suzanne Moore |author-link=Suzanne Moore |date=21 September 2015 |title=The David Cameron #piggate storm is a sideshow from the real issues. It’s certainly effective |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2015/sep/21/david-cameron-piggate-sideshow-dead-pig }}</ref>
Journalist Solomon Hughes has argued that Ashcroft "has an 18th century attitude towards buying a place in government" and says that Ashcroft thought that his donations to the Conservative Party would provide him with a "shortcut" to a ministerial position. He says that when Cameron "didn't let Ashcroft buy a place in government" Ashcroft filled his book with "barely political smears". Hughes argues that this means the book "tells us something about our political world, but not much about David Cameron".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.vice.com/read/lord-ashcroft-the-man-behind-call-me-dave-001|title=What the Story of the Billionaire Behind Pig-Gate Tells Us About British Politics|work=Vice|accessdate=27 September 2015}}</ref>
Claims were made that the story was deliberately avoided by some media sources. The initial decision not to report on the anecdote by the BBC and some other broadcasters was criticised by the assistant editor of ''The Independent'', Ian Burrell, who described its choice to "dodge" the story of the day as "unacceptable".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/comment/the-bbcs-refusal-to-report-the-dead-pig-allegations-against-david-cameron-is-unacceptable-10511162.html|title=The BBC's decision not to report the dead pig allegations against David Cameron is unacceptable|work=The Independent|location=London|first=Ian|last=Burrell|accessdate=21 September 2015}}</ref> The BBC covered the story from 21 September.<ref>{{cite news|title=Lord Ashcroft 'not settling scores' with David Cameron book|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-34312744|accessdate=23 September 2015|publisher=BBC News|date=21 September 2015}}</ref>
The publication of the anecdote elicited responses from other politicians as well as media such as a clip by [[Cassetteboy]] parodying [[Will Smith]]'s song "[[Gettin' Jiggy wit It]]"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2015/09/21/politicians-begin-to-respond-to-david-cameron-pig-gate-allegations_n_8169622.html|title=Politicians Smell Blood As They Begin To Respond To David Cameron #PigGate Allegations|work=Huffington Post|accessdate=23 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.westernmorningnews.co.uk/Councillors-poke-fun-Cameron-piggate-scandal/story-27844221-detail/story.html|title=Councillors poke fun at Cameron piggate scandal|work=Western Morning News|accessdate=22 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://metro.co.uk/2015/09/21/some-genius-has-mashed-up-david-camerons-speeches-into-gettin-piggy-with-it-5401675/|title=Cassetteboy has mashed up David Cameron’s speeches into ‘Gettin’ Piggy With it’|work=Metro|accessdate=22 September 2015}}</ref> and an animated enactment from [[Next Media Animation]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bloom|first1=Dan|title=Taiwanese animators take on PigGate — and it's every bit as horrible as you think|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/taiwanese-animators-take-piggate-its-6490625|accessdate=23 September 2015|date=22 September 2015}}</ref> [[HBO]]'s satirical news program, ''[[Last Week Tonight with John Oliver]]'', also covered the published anecdote, saying 'bizarre is a kind way of describing it'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2015/09/28/john-oliver-mocks-noted-swine-fellatio-enthusiast-david-cameron.html|title=John Oliver Mocks ‘Noted Swine Fellatio Enthusiast’ David Cameron|work=The Daily Beast|accessdate=28 September 2015}}</ref>
[[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] leader [[Jeremy Corbyn]] criticised the media's handling of the accusations, telling [[ITV News]]: "The media treatment of any politician [over] unsubstantiated allegations, be it David Cameron, me or anyone else is wrong, too much of our media is obsessed with personality politics."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2015/09/24/piggate-jeremy-corbyn-real-issues_n_8191464.html |title=Jeremy Corbyn Says Piggate Scandal Risks Distracting From Real Issues And World Peace |work=Huffington Post |date=24 September 2015}}</ref>
[[UKIP]] leader [[Nigel Farage]] referred to the matter in the context of the upcoming British [[European Union]] [[referendum]]. After noting that there was the "In" campaign and the "Out" camp, he reflected: "And then we've got the Prime Minister. Or should I call him, in this context, piggy in the middle".<ref name="dathan">{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/nigel-farage-mocks-david-cameron-with-piggy-in-the-middle-jibe-10516619.html|title=Nigel Farage mocks David Cameron with 'piggy in the middle' jibe|author=Matt Dathan|date=25 September 2015|work=The Independent|location=London}}</ref> [[Nicola Sturgeon]] of the [[Scottish National Party|SNP]] also made reference to the incident, accusing Cameron of being "pig-headed" with regards to the [[Scottish independence referendum, 2014]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Dathan|first1=Matt|title=Nicola Sturgeon makes 'piggate' joke with accusation that David Cameron is 'pig-headed'|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/nicola-sturgeon-makes-piggate-joke-with-accusation-that-david-cameron-is-pig-headed-a6698121.html|accessdate=12 December 2015|work=The Independent|date=17 October 2015}}</ref>
On 4 October 2015, a protest rally outside the Conservative Party conference in [[Manchester]] city centre was attended by a reported 60,000 people. A number of demonstrators carried signs or wore costume items referring to the anecdote.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/oct/04/anti-austerity-protestors-march-manchester-demonstration-conservative-party-conference|title=Anti-austerity protesters march on conservative conference|author=Pidd, Helen|date=4 October 2015|work=The Guardian|location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.express.co.uk/news/politics/609868/Manchester-anti-austerity-march-Tory-conference-turns-ugly|date=5 October 2015|title=Tories get egged as anti-austerity protesters taunt Cameron over 'pig-gate'|work=Daily Express|location=London}}</ref> At one of the country's biggest [[Guy Fawkes Night|Bonfire night]] celebrations in [[Lewes]], a large effigy of Cameron with a pig's head was processed through the town and then burnt.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-sussex-34731830|title=Lewes Bonfire Society torches David Cameron effigy|publisher=BBC|date=5 November 2015|first=Nathalie|last=Edell}}</ref>
In November 2015, solicitor [[Myles Jackman]] said that performing a sexual act with a dead animal would not be illegal under the [[Sexual Offences Act 2003]]. He noted that possessing a photograph of such an act would be illegal under the [[Criminal Justice and Immigration Act 2008]] if it was produced for pornographic purposes, but not if the purpose was "satire, political commentary or simple grossness".<ref name=Jackman>{{cite web|last1=Jackman|first1=Myles|title=Is it illegal to have sex with a dead pig? Here's what the law says about the allegations surrounding David Cameron's biography|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/comment/is-it-illegal-to-have-sex-with-a-dead-pig-heres-what-the-law-says-about-the-allegations-surrounding-10510743.html|website=The Independent|accessdate=30 November 2015}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Hazing]]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2018}} {{Use mdy dates|date=June 2017}} {{Infobox person |name = Reality Winner |birth_name = Reality Leigh Winner |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1991|12|4}} |birth_place = [[Alice, Texas]], U.S.<ref name=AJC2017-06-11>{{cite web |last1=Brett |first1=Jennifer |last2=Edwards |first2=Johnny |url=https://www.pressreader.com/usa/the-atlanta-journal-constitution/20170611/281496456263152 |title=Family and friends recall a life that somehow unraveled |work=[[The Atlanta Journal-Constitution]] |date=June 11, 2017 |accessdate=September 28, 2017}}</ref> |death_date = |death_place = |residence = [[Augusta, Georgia]] |occupation = Intelligence specialist |years_active = 4 to 6 months |employer = Pluribus International Corporation |known_for = Leaking an intelligence report detailing [[Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections]] to ''[[The Intercept]]'' |home_town = [[Kingsville, Texas]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/06/06/politics/reality-winner-who-is-accused-leaker/index.html |title=What we know about Reality Winner |first=Madison |last=Park |publisher=[[CNN]] |date=June 6, 2017 |accessdate=June 6, 2017}}</ref> |criminal_charge = [[Espionage Act of 1917|18 U.S. Code § 793(e)]]{{snd}} Gathering, transmitting or losing national defense information<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.usnews.com/news/national-news/articles/2017-06-06/reality-leigh-winner-details-emerge-on-suspected-nsa-leaker|title=Who Is Reality Leigh Winner? |date=June 6, 2017 |accessdate=June 6, 2017 |work=[[U.S. News & World Report]]}}</ref> |criminal_penalty = Five years and three months in prison |criminal_status = Pleaded guilty |module = {{Infobox military person |embed = yes |allegiance = {{flag|United States}} |branch = {{flag|United States Air Force}} |serviceyears = 2010–2016<ref name="a">{{cite web |url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2017/06/06/who-is-reality-winner-accused-leaker-wanted-to-resist-trump.html|title=Who is Reality Winner? Accused leaker wanted to 'resist' Trump |first=Brooke |last=Singman |date=June 6, 2017 |accessdate=June 6, 2017 |publisher=Fox News}}</ref> |rank = [[File:E4 USAF SAM.svg|15px]] [[Senior airman]] (E-4)<ref name="a"/> |unit = [[707th Intelligence, Surveillance and Reconnaissance Group|94th Intelligence Squadron]]<ref name="a"/> |awards = [[Air Force Commendation Medal]]}} }} '''Reality Leigh Winner''' (born December 4, 1991)<ref name=SearchWarrant2017-06-03>{{cite web |url=https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/3848398-Reality-Winner-Affidavit-for-Application-of.html#document/p2/a356449 |title=Application for a Search Warrant |website=United States District Court for the Southern District of Georgia |date=June 3, 2017 |accessdate=September 28, 2017}}</ref> <!-- EDITOR NOTE: The preceding URL is embedded in separate reference cited herein as <ref name=NYTimes2017-06-07> --> is a former American intelligence specialist. In 2017, she was charged with "removing classified material from a government facility and mailing it to a news outlet." The material in question originated with the [[National Security Agency]] (NSA).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.politico.com/story/2017/09/27/reality-winner-nsa-document-pantyhose-243236 |title=Alleged leaker Reality Winner said she stuffed NSA report in her pantyhose |publisher=}}</ref>
On June 3, 2017, while employed by the military contractor Pluribus International Corporation, Winner was arrested on suspicion of [[News leak|leaking]] an intelligence report about [[Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections]] to the news website ''[[The Intercept]]''. The report suggested that Russian hackers had accessed at least one U.S. voting-software supplier.<ref name="intercept">{{cite news |title=Whatever You Think of the Trump-Russia Investigation, Whistleblower Reality Winner Deserves Your Support |url=https://theintercept.com/2018/06/02/reality-winner-whistleblower-without-constituency/ |work=The Intercept |date=June 2, 2018}}</ref> Twice denied [[bail]], Winner was held at the Lincoln County Jail in [[Lincolnton, Georgia]].<ref>{{citeweb |url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/06/08/532063648/federal-grand-jury-indicts-accused-nsa-leaker-reality-winner |title=Accused NSA Leaker Reality Winner To Remain In Jail Pending Trial}}</ref><ref>{{citeweb |url=http://www.ajc.com/news/local-govt--politics/nsa-leak-case-paint-two-portraits-reality-winner/XyCU0wNOJIw1sF8FANUs0N/ |title=NSA leak case to paint two portraits of Reality Winner}}</ref> On August 23, 2018, Winner was sentenced to five years and three months in prison as part of a plea deal.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theverge.com/2018/6/26/17503656/reality-winner-guilty-plea-agreement-prison-time |title=Reality Winner accepts guilty plea for 63 months in prison on espionage charge |publisher=The Verge |date=2018-06-26 }}</ref>
==Early life and education== Winner grew up in [[Kingsville, Texas]] and was a 2010 graduate of [[H. M. King High School]], where she learned Arabic and played on the soccer and tennis teams.<ref>{{cite news |last=Vejnoska |first=Jill |url=https://www.ajc.com/blog/buzz/the-https://www.mypalmbeachpost.com/news/national/who-reality-winner-the-sentenced-nsa-leaker/75W29nNzr7UnnUWdbpVNtM/ |title=Who is Reality Winner, the sentenced NSA leaker? |work=MyPalmBeachPost.com |publisher=The Atlanta Journal-Constitution |date=2018-08-23 |accessdate=2018-08-24 }}</ref>
== Career == Winner served in the [[United States Air Force]] from 2010 to 2016, achieving the rank of [[senior airman]] (an [[U.S. uniformed services pay grades#Enlisted pay grades|E-4 paygrade]]) with the 94th Intelligence Squadron.<ref>{{cite web |last=Ortiz |first=Erik |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/who-reality-winner-nsa-contractor-accused-top-secret-leak-n768661 |title=Who Is Reality Winner, NSA Contractor Accused in Top Secret Leak? |publisher=NBC News |date= |accessdate=June 8, 2017}}</ref><ref name="a"/> After two years of language and intelligence training, she was posted to [[Fort George G. Meade|Fort Meade, Maryland]].<ref name=NewYorkMag>{{cite web |last=Howley |first=Kerry |url=http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2017/12/who-is-reality-winner.html |title=The World's Biggest Terrorist Has a Pikachu Bedspread |work=[[New York (magazine)|New York]] |date=December 22, 2017 |accessdate=December 22, 2017}}</ref> She worked as a cryptologic linguist, being fluent in the [[Persian language]] and in [[Dari language|Dari]], the Persian dialect spoken in Afghanistan, as well as in [[Pashto]].<ref>{{citation |last=Bainbridge |first=William Sims |url=https://ieet.org/index.php/IEET2/more/Bainbridge20170714 |title=Is Reality Winner "One of Us?" |journal=Ethical Technology |publisher=The [[Institute for Ethics and Emerging Technologies]] |date=July 14, 2017 |accessdate=September 4, 2017}}</ref> Assigned to the drone program,<ref name=NewYorkMag/> she listened in on intercepted foreign chatter to provide U.S. forces with intelligence.<ref name="guardian">{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/jun/06/reality-winner-profile-nsa-trump-isis |title=Reality Winner: NSA contractor and environmentalist repulsed by Trump |last=Swaine |first=Jon |date=June 6, 2017 |work=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=June 7, 2017}}</ref> Winner was awarded the [[Air Force Commendation Medal]] for "aiding in 650 enemy captures, 600 enemies killed in action and identifying 900 high[-]value targets."<ref>{{cite web |last=Edwards |first=John |url=http://www.ajc.com/news/national/air-force-honored-reality-winner-for-taking-out-enemy-combatants/XoEbupm6P318Eun9ZGOo1O/ |title=Air Force honored Reality Winner for taking out enemy combatants |work=The Atlanta Journal-Constitution |date=June 7, 2017 |accessdate=June 8, 2017}}</ref>
A month after being honorably discharged from the Air Force in November 2016, Winner moved to [[Augusta, Georgia]], where she taught at [[CrossFit]] and at a yoga studio.<ref name=NewYorkMag/> Still possessing a [[Classified information|top-secret]] [[security clearance]],<ref name=NewYorkMag/> Winner was then hired by Pluribus International Corporation, a small firm<ref name=NewYorkMag/> that provides services under contract to the National Security Agency.<ref name=NYTimes2017-06-07/><ref name=AtlanticWhoIsWinner/><ref name=AtlantaJournal2017-06-05>{{cite news |url = http://www.myajc.com/news/breaking-news/augusta-contractor-charged-with-mishandling-top-secret-materials/VFqwwNvxTBe7w2BxkQaWNM/ |title= Augusta contractor charged with mishandling top-secret U.S. materials |publisher= [[Atlanta Journal Constitution]] |author= Jeremy Redmon |date= June 5, 2017 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170606053247/http://www.myajc.com/news/breaking-news/augusta-contractor-charged-with-mishandling-top-secret-materials/VFqwwNvxTBe7w2BxkQaWNM/ |archivedate = June 6, 2017 |accessdate= June 9, 2017 |deadurl= No |quote= The government announced Reality Leigh Winner's arrest Monday, about an hour after The Intercept reported that it had obtained a top-secret National Security Agency report about Russia's interference.}}</ref><ref name=AtlantaJournal2017-06-09>{{cite news |url= http://www.myajc.com/news/national-govt--politics/accused-leaker-social-posts-not-enough-shake-top-secret-clearance/7524nEeXmwkzFLuYWBg35H/ |title = Accused leaker's social posts not enough to shake top secret clearance |publisher= [[Atlanta Journal Constitution]] |author= Danny Robbins; Christian Boone; J. Scott Trubey |date= June 9, 2017 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170609144318/http://www.myajc.com/news/national-govt--politics/accused-leaker-social-posts-not-enough-shake-top-secret-clearance/7524nEeXmwkzFLuYWBg35H/ |archivedate = June 9, 2017 |deadurl= No |quote= Winner's posts deriding President Trump likely wouldn't trigger interest from NSA personnel unless someone complained, experts said. And even if someone did, deciding whether to take some sort of action would be a difficult call, they said.}}</ref> On February 13, 2017, Pluribus assigned her to work at [[Fort Gordon]],<ref>{{cite web |last=Park |first=Madison |url=http://www.kvia.com/news/politics/what-we-know-about-reality-winner/529922707 |title=What we know about Reality Winner |date=June 6, 2017 |publisher=[[KVIA-TV|KVIA]] |accessdate=June 6, 2017}}</ref> a U.S. Army post near Augusta, where she had once been stationed while in the Air Force.<ref name=NewYorkMag/> Assigned to translate documents relating to Iran's aerospace program from Persian,<ref name=NewYorkMag/> Winner was employed by Pluribus at the time of her arrest for unauthorized disclosure of classified documents.<ref name=AtlantaJournal2017-06-07>{{cite news |url= http://www.myajc.com/news/breaking-news/augusta-center-nsa-leak-investigation/0VWpzWLHe0FZmBKOC5DhgL/ |title= Augusta at center of NSA leak investigation: City is major hub for intelligence community |publisher= [[Atlanta Journal Constitution]] |author= J. Scott Trubey; Jennifer Peebles; Jeremy Redmon |date= June 7, 2017 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170609144607/http://www.myajc.com/news/breaking-news/augusta-center-nsa-leak-investigation/0VWpzWLHe0FZmBKOC5DhgL/ |archivedate = June 9, 2017 |deadurl= No|quote= As Winner's story unfolded this week, reporters from major networks and newspapers across the country descended here. But few people attached to the military installation would talk on the record. The NSA declined to comment. Local government officials were also tight-lipped.}}</ref>
On February 11, 2017, just two days before she began employment as an NSA contractor, she wrote on her [[Twitter]] account that "the most dangerous entry to this country was the orange fascist we let into the White House".<ref>{{cite web |title=Accused leaker Reality Winner called Trump an 'orange fascist' on Twitter |url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/06/06/politics/reality-winner-twitter-account/index.html |publisher=CNN |last=O'Sullivan |first=Donie |date=June 6, 2017 |accessdate=June 7, 2017}}</ref> She described President [[Donald Trump]] as "a soulless ginger orangutan" on her [[Facebook page]].<ref name="washtimes">{{cite web |url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2017/jun/6/reality-winners-facebook-page-fills-with-rage/ |title=Suspected leaker’s Facebook page filled with vitriol against Trump |work=The Washington Times |date=June 6, 2017 |accessdate=June 6, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Accused NSA leaker Reality Winner's motives a 'mystery' – At least to ABC, NBC and CBS |url=http://www.foxnews.com/opinion/2017/06/07/accused-nsa-leaker-reality-winners-motives-mystery-at-least-to-abc-nbc-and-cbs.html |publisher=Fox News |last=Fondacaro |first=Nicholas |date=June 7, 2017 |accessdate=June 7, 2017}}</ref> Prior to the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 presidential election]], she posted: "On a positive note, this Tuesday when we become the United States of the Russian Federation, Olympic lifting will be the national sport."<ref name="fox"/>
Federal agents found her diary during a search of her home, in which she allegedly expressed support for [[Taliban]] leaders and [[Osama bin Laden]].<ref name=bailbloom>{{cite web |last=Hurtado |first=Patricia |title=Accused Leaker of Top-Secret U.S. Report Loses Bail Request |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170627093354/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-06-08/accused-leaker-is-indicted-for-disclosing-classified-report |website=Bloomberg.com |accessdate=August 24, 2018 |date=June 8, 2017}}</ref> The U.S. magistrate judge who presided over Winner's bail hearing said: "She seems to have a fascination with the Middle East and Islamic terrorism," and quoted her writing: "It's a Christlike vision to have a fundamentalist Islamic state."<ref name=bailbloom/> However, one of the prosecutors at her bail hearing said: "The government is not in any way suggesting the defendant has become a jihadist or that she is a Taliban sympathizer."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Clark |first1=Johnny |last2=Bynum |first2=Russ |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/reality-winner-denied-bail-2017-6 |title=Judge denies bail for alleged NSA leaker Reality Winner |work=Business Insider |date=June 8, 2017 |accessdate=June 12, 2017 |via=Associated Press}}</ref>
== Intelligence report leak, arrest and sentencing == Winner was arrested on June 3, 2017. The U.S. Department of Justice announced her arrest on June 5,<ref>{{cite web |last1=Silva |first1=Daniella |last2=Grosenick |first2=Kip |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/reality-winner-alleged-nsa-leaker-will-plead-not-guilty-lawyer-n769526 |title=Alleged NSA leaker Reality Winner to plead not guilty |work=NBC News |date=June 7, 2017 |accessdate=June 8, 2017}}</ref> shortly after ''The Intercept'' published an article describing Russian attempts to interfere with the 2016 presidential election by [[Security hacker|hacking]] a U.S. voting software supplier and sending [[Phishing#Spear phishing|spear-phishing]] emails to more than 100 local election officials just days before the November 8 election. ''The Intercept''{{'s}} story was based on a [[top-secret]] May 5, 2017, National Security Agency (NSA) document leaked to them anonymously.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Cole|first1=Matthew|last2=Esposito|first2=Richard|last3=Biddle|first3=Sam|last4=Grim|first4=Ryan|title=Top-Secret NSA Report Details Russian Hacking Effort Days Before 2016 Election|url=https://theintercept.com/2017/06/05/top-secret-nsa-report-details-russian-hacking-effort-days-before-2016-election/|accessdate=June 6, 2017|work=The Intercept|publisher=First Look Media|date=June 5, 2017}}</ref>
''The Intercept'' had contacted the NSA on May 30 and sent copies of the documents in order to confirm their veracity. The NSA notified the FBI of the situation on June 1. According to media coverage published in VICE, an official report from the FBI noted the documents "appeared to be folded and/or creased, suggesting they had been printed and hand-carried out of a secured space."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gilbert|first1=David|title=NSA leak suspect was ratted out by an office printer|url=https://news.vice.com/story/nsa-leak-suspect-was-ratted-out-by-an-office-printer|accessdate=June 6, 2017|publisher=[[Vice News]]|date=June 6, 2017}}</ref> Next, the NSA did an internal audit, confirming that Winner was one of six workers who had accessed the particular documents on its classified system, but only Winner's computer had been in contact with ''The Intercept'' using a personal email account. On June 3, the FBI obtained a warrant to search Winner's electronic devices, and she was arrested.<ref name=bailbloom/> Both journalists and security experts have suggested that ''The Intercept''{{'s}} handling of the reporting, which included publishing the documents unredacted and including the [[printer tracking dots]], was used to identify Winner as the leaker.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://digg.com/2017/did-intercept-burn-reality-winner|title=Did The Intercept Betray Its NSA Source With Sloppy Reporting?|first=L.V.|last=Anderson|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|date=June 6, 2017 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/erik-wemple/wp/2017/06/06/did-the-intercept-bungle-nsa-leak/|title=Did the Intercept bungle the NSA leak?|first=Erik|last=Wemple|work=Washington Post}}</ref>
In an 'Affidavit in Support of Application for Arrest Warrant' dated July 5, 2017, FBI Special Agent Justin C. Garrick stated: {{block quote|On June 3, 2017, your affiant spoke to WINNER at her home in Augusta, Georgia. During that conversation, WINNER admitted intentionally identifying and printing the classified intelligence reporting at issue despite not having a "need to know," and with knowledge that the intelligence reporting was classified. WINNER further admitted removing the classified intelligence reporting from her office space, retaining it, and mailing it from Augusta, Georgia, to the News Outlet, which she knew was not authorized to receive or possess the documents.{{pb}} WINNER further acknowledged that she was aware of the contents of the intelligence reporting and that she knew the contents of the reporting could be used to the injury of the United States and to the advantage of a foreign nation.{{pb}} CONCLUSION{{pb}} Your affiant submits that the facts set forth in this affidavit establish probable cause to believe WINNER committed a violation of 18 U.S.C. Section 793(e). Therefore, your affiant respectfully requests this Court issue an arrest warrant for WINNER.<ref name=USDoJ5Jun2017/>}}
[[Julian Assange]], the founder of [[WikiLeaks]], called on the public to support Winner,<ref name="fox">"{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2017/06/06/who-is-reality-winner-accused-leaker-wanted-to-resist-trump.html|title=Who is Reality Winner? Accused leaker wanted to 'resist' Trump|publisher=Fox News|date=June 6, 2017|accessdate=June 6, 2017}}</ref> offering a $10,000 reward for information about a reporter for ''The Intercept'' who had allegedly helped the U.S. government identify Winner as the leaker.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thehill.com/policy/cybersecurity/336518-wikileaks-offering-10000-to-get-intercept-reporter-fired|title=WikiLeaks offers $10,000 to get Intercept reporter fired|work=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]|date=June 6, 2017|accessdate=June 6, 2017}}</ref> Assange wrote on Twitter that "Winner is no [[James Clapper|Clapper]] or [[David Petraeus|Petraeus]] with 'elite immunity'. She's a young woman against the wall for talking to the press."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.express.co.uk/news/uk/813857/Wikileaks-Julian-Assange-tweets-support-Reality-Leigh-Winner-Russia-leak-The-Intercept|title=Wikileaks' Julian Assange tweets support for NSA 'whistleblower' Reality Leigh Winner|work=[[Daily Express]]|date=June 6, 2017|accessdate=June 6, 2017}}</ref>
Winner was charged with "removing classified material from a government facility and mailing it to a news outlet."<ref name=USDoJ5Jun2017>{{cite web |url =https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/federal-government-contractor-georgia-charged-removing-and-mailing-classified-materials-news | title =Federal Government Contractor in Georgia Charged With Removing and Mailing Classified Materials to a News Outlet | date =June 5, 2017 | publisher =US Justice Department |accessdate = September 3, 2017}} {{PD-notice}}</ref> On June 8, 2017, she pleaded not guilty to a charge of "willful retention and transmission of national defense information", and was denied [[bail]]. Prosecutors alleged she may have been involved in other leaks of classified information, and might try to flee the country if released.<ref name="bailbloom"/><ref>{{cite web |last=Hartmann |first=Margaret |url=http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2017/06/alleged-leaker-reality-winner-pleads-not-guilty-denied-bail.html |title=Alleged Leaker Reality Winner Pleads Not Guilty, Is Denied Bail |work=New York Magazine |date=June 8, 2017 |accessdate=June 9, 2017}}</ref> The U.S. Justice Department lawyers also argued that her defense team should not be allowed to discuss any classified information, even if it was in news reports published by the media.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.law.com/sites/almstaff/2017/07/11/prosecutors-in-reality-winner-case-push-for-news-reports-to-be-classified|title=Prosecutors in Reality Winner Case Push for News Reports to Be 'Classified'|author=|date=|website=www.law.com|accessdate=August 7, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://chronicle.augusta.com/news/2017-07-11/prosecutors-seek-order-silence-defense-classified-information-reality-winner-case|title=Prosecutors seek order to silence defense on classified information in Reality Winner case|author=|date=|website=augusta.com|accessdate=August 7, 2017}}</ref>
On August 29, 2017, Winner's attorneys filed a motion in U.S. District Court to suppress her statements to law enforcement, arguing that Winner was not read her [[Miranda warning|"Miranda" rights]] before being interrogated by the FBI on June 3.<ref>{{cite web|last=Greenwood|first=Max|url=http://thehill.com/policy/cybersecurity/348532-reality-winner-moves-to-suppress-confession|title=Accused leaker Reality Winner moves to suppress statements to police|work=The Hill|date=September 1, 2017|accessdate=September 1, 2017}}</ref> On October 5, 2017, Judge Brian Epps denied a second request from her defense attorneys that bail be set.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://theintercept.com/2017/10/06/nsa-reality-winner-judge-denies-bail/|title=Judge Denies Bail for Reality Winner, Accepting Prosecutor's Dubious Allegations|first=Trevor|last=Timm|date=October 6, 2017|publisher=The Intercept}}</ref> In December 2017, ''The Intercept'' reported that Winner's defense team is allowed to discuss the case with her, including its classified aspects, in a [[Sensitive Compartmented Information Facility|"sensitive compartmented information facility"]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://theintercept.com/2017/12/05/reality-winner-trial-nsa-russia-election/|title=The Government is trying to make it impossible for Reality Winner to defend herself in court|first=Trevor|last=Timm|date=December 5, 2017|publisher=The Intercept}}</ref>
On January 31, 2018, the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit|U.S. Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit]] affirmed a lower court order blocking Winner from posting bond, determining that no combination of conditions would reasonably assure her presence at trial, thus ensuring that she remains in jail until her trial,<ref>{{cite web|last=McDonald|first=R. Robin|url=https://www.law.com/dailyreportonline/sites/dailyreportonline/2018/01/31/eleventh-circuit-rules-that-accused-media-leaker-must-remain-jailed-until-trial/|title=Eleventh Circuit Rules That Accused Media Leaker Must Remain Jailed Until Trial|work=Daily Report|date=January 31, 2018|accessdate=February 1, 2018}}</ref> which was scheduled to begin on October 15, 2018.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://politics.myajc.com/news/state--regional-govt--politics/reality-winner-nsa-leak-trial-augusta-postponed-second-time/GcPia7Nh3Ll9NPG2QVFcUL/|title=Reality Winner’s NSA leak trial in Augusta postponed a second time|work=politics.myajc|access-date=March 16, 2018|language=en}}</ref>
A "Stand with Reality" campaign was formed by representatives from [[Courage to Resist]], the [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]] and the [[Freedom of the Press Foundation]] with the goal of "raising public awareness" to ensure that Reality Winner receives a fair trial.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://standwithreality.org/|title="Stand with Reality" Support Group & Defense Fund|website=Friends of Reality Winner}}</ref> Billie Winner-Davis, mother of Reality Winner, called on members of the public to join this campaign.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://standwithreality.org/democracy-now-interviews-reality-winners-mom/|title=Democracy Now! interview with Reality Winner's mom|date=March 2, 2018|publisher=}}</ref>
On June 21, 2018, Winner asked the court to allow her to change her plea to guilty<ref>{{cite web| agency=Reuters | accessdate=August 23, 2018 | url=https://af.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idAFKBN1JI0D3 |title=Reality Winner to change her plea on leaking Russian interference report |date=June 22, 2018 |first=Brendan |last=O'Brien}}</ref> and on June 26 she pleaded guilty to one count of felony transmission of national defense information.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/26/us/reality-winner-nsa-leak-guilty-plea.html |title=Reality Winner, N.S.A. Contractor Accused in Leak, Pleads Guilty |last=Savage |first=Charlie |date=June 26, 2018 |work=The New York Times |access-date=June 26, 2018 |last2=Blinder |first2=Alan |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://theintercept.com/2018/06/26/reality-winner-plea-deal/ |title=Whistleblower Reality Winner, Charged Under the Espionage Act for Helping to Inform Public of Russian Election Meddling, Pleads Guilty |last=Timm |first=Trevor |date=June 26, 2018 |work=The Intercept |access-date=June 26, 2018 }}</ref> Winner's plea agreement with prosecutors called for her to serve five years and three months in prison followed by three years of supervised release.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.myajc.com/news/state--regional-govt--politics/reality-winner-pleads-guilty-all-these-actions-did-willfully/zmGG8vtG0A4apJkTbGwjYP/|title=Reality Winner pleads guilty: 'All of these actions I did willfully'|work=The Atlanta Journal-Constitution |access-date=June 26, 2018}}</ref>
On August 23, 2018, at a federal court in Georgia, Winner was sentenced to the agreed-upon five years and three months in prison for violating the [[Espionage Act of 1917|Espionage Act]]. Prosecutors said her sentence was the longest ever imposed in federal court for an unauthorized release of government information to the media.<ref name=NYT23Aug2018>{{cite news|last=Philipps|first=Dave|date=August 23, 2018|title=Reality Winner, Former N.S.A. Translator, Gets More Than 5 Years in Leak of Russian Hacking Report|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/08/23/us/reality-winner-nsa-sentence.html|work=The New York Times|access-date=August 25, 2018}}</ref> ''[[The New York Times]]'' reported, "Under the plea agreement, Ms. Winner will be transferred to the [[Federal Bureau of Prisons]]' [[Federal Medical Center, Carswell|medical center in Carswell, Tex.]], where she can receive treatment for [[Bulimia nervosa|bulimia]] and be relatively close to her family."<ref name=NYT23Aug2018/> As of August 31, she remained at the Lincoln County Jail, where she has been incarcerated for more than a year, awaiting transfer.<ref name=AJC31Aug2018>{{cite news|last=Edwards|first=Johnny|date=August 31, 2018|title=Reality Winner will ask Trump to reverse her 'so unfair' prison sentence|url=https://www.myajc.com/news/crime--law/reality-winner-will-ask-trump-reverse-her-unfair-prison-sentence/Edo5PhgPngEkGUyenmqiIL/|work=The Atlanta Journal-Constitution|access-date=September 3, 2018}}</ref>
On August 24, President Trump tweeted: "Ex-NSA contractor to spend 63 months in jail over 'classified' information. Gee, this is 'small potatoes' compared to what [[Hillary Clinton email controversy|Hillary Clinton]] did! So unfair [[Jeff Sessions|Jeff]], Double Standard." Winner expressed appreciation for his support, saying, "I can't thank him enough."<ref>{{Cite news|title=Jailed NSA leaker Reality Winner on Trump "so unfair" tweet: "I can't thank him enough"|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/reality-winner-former-nsa-contractor-deeply-regrets-leaking-classified-documents/|access-date=August 30, 2018|work=CBS News|date=August 30, 2018}}</ref> On August 31, Winner said she will ask Trump for clemency as a result of his tweet, and that her legal team was already working on her pardon application.<ref name=AJC31Aug2018/>
== See also == * [[Timeline of Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections]]
== References == {{reflist|30em|refs= <ref name=NYTimes2017-06-07> {{cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/06/us/politics/reality-leigh-winner-leak-nsa.html | title = Reality Winner, N.S.A. Contractor Accused of Leak, Was Undone by Trail of Clues | work = The New York Times | author = [[Charlie Savage]], [[Scott Shane]], [[Alan Blinder]] | date = June 6, 2017 | page = A19 | location = | archiveurl = | archivedate = | accessdate = June 7, 2017 | deadurl = No | quote = Ms. Winner's apparent Twitter feed, which used a pseudonym but had a photo of her and the same account name as her Instagram feed, makes clear her hostility toward Mr. Trump. That suggests a possible motive for leaking: highlighting Russian hacking of election-related targets, amplifying the narrative that Mr. Trump's victory is tainted. }} </ref>
<ref name=AtlanticWhoIsWinner> {{cite news | url = https://www.theatlantic.com/news/archive/2017/06/who-is-reality-winner/529266/ | title = Who Is Reality Winner? | publisher = [[The Atlantic]] | author = Krishnadev Calamur | date = June 6, 2017 | page = | location = | archiveurl = | archivedate = | accessdate = June 7, 2017 | deadurl = No | quote = }} </ref> }}
